leanCodeSectionsTree.displayTitle: Chapter 7 Fire and Smoke Protection Features

children.body: The provisions of this chapter shall govern the materials, systems and assemblies used for structural fire resistance and fire-resistance-rated construction separation of adjacent spaces to safeguard against the spread of fire and smoke within a building and the spread of fire to or from buildings.
Fire assemblies that serve multiple purposes in a building shall comply with all of the requirements that are applicable for each of the individual fire assemblies.

The following terms are defined in Chapter 2:

ANNULAR SPACE.

BUILDING ELEMENT.

CEILING RADIATION DAMPER.

COMBINATION FIRE/SMOKE DAMPER.

CORRIDOR DAMPER.

DAMPER.

DRAFTSTOP

F RATING.

FIRE BARRIER.

FIRE DAMPER.

FIRE DOOR.

FIRE DOOR ASSEMBLY.

FIRE PARTITION.

FIRE PROTECTION RATING.

FIRE-RATED GLAZING.

FIRE RESISTANCE.

FIRE-RESISTANCE RATING.

FIRE-RESISTANT JOINT SYSTEM.

FIRE SEPARATION DISTANCE.

FIRE WALL.

FIRE WINDOW ASSEMBLY.

FIREBLOCKING.

FLOOR FIRE DOOR ASSEMBLY.

HORIZONTAL ASSEMBLY.

JOINT.

L RATING.

MEMBRANE PENETRATION.

MEMBRANE-PENETRATION FIRESTOP.

MEMBRANE-PENETRATION FIRESTOP SYSTEM.

MINERAL FIBER.

MINERAL WOOL.

PENETRATION FIRESTOP.

SELF-CLOSING.

SHAFT.

SHAFT ENCLOSURE.

SMOKE BARRIER.

SMOKE COMPARTMENT.

SMOKE DAMPER.

SPLICE.

T RATING.

THROUGH PENETRATION.

THROUGH-PENETRATION FIRESTOP SYSTEM.

children.displayTitle: Section 703 Fire-Resistance Ratings and Fire Tests

children.body: Materials prescribed herein for fire resistance shall conform to the requirements of this chapter.

The fire-resistance rating of building elements, components or assemblies shall be determined in accordance with the test procedures set forth in ASTM E119 or UL 263 or in accordance with Section 703.3. The fire-resistance rating of penetrations and fire-resistant joint systems shall be determined in accordance Sections 714 and 715, respectively.

Interior walls and partitions of nonsymmetrical construction shall be tested with both faces exposed to the furnace, and the assigned fire-resistance rating shall be the shortest duration obtained from the two tests conducted in compliance with ASTM E119 or UL 263. Where evidence is furnished to show that the wall was tested with the least fire-resistant side exposed to the furnace, subject to acceptance of the building official, the wall need not be subjected to tests from the opposite side (see Section 705.5 for exterior walls).

Combustible aggregates are permitted in gypsum and Portland cement concrete mixtures for fire-resistance-rated construction. Any component material or admixture is permitted in assemblies if the resulting tested assembly meets the fire-resistance test requirements of this code.

Fire-resistance-rated assemblies tested under ASTM E119 or UL 263 shall not be considered to be restrained unless evidence satisfactory to the building official is furnished by the registered design professional showing that the construction qualifies for a restrained classification in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263. Restrained construction shall be identified on the construction documents.

diagrams.title: Fire Ratings: Conc. Slabs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Life Safety Code, "Fire resistance-rated floor and roof assemblies shall be classified as restrained or unrestrained in accordance with ASTM E119, Standard Test Methods for Fire Tests of Building Construction and Materials, or ANSI/UL 263, Standard for Fire Tests of Building Construction and Materials', or other approved test methods. The construction shall be considered restrained only where a registered design professional has furnished the authority having jurisdiction with satisfactory documentation verifying that the construction is restrained. The classification of fire resistance-rated floor and roof construction shall be identified on the plans as restrained or unrestrained."

Restraint is provided when adjacent structural elements not under the influence of a fire are able to provide lateral restraint to prevent the expansion of materials in the plane of a roof or floor assembly, such as a concrete slab, because of a fire below.

children.body: Where materials, systems or devices that have not been tested as part of a fire-resistance-rated assembly are incorporated into the building element, component or assembly, sufficient data shall be made available to the building official to show that the required fire-resistance rating is not reduced.

In determining the fire-resistance rating of exterior bearing walls, compliance with the ASTM E119 or UL 263 criteria for unexposed surface temperature rise and ignition of cotton waste due to passage of flame or gases is required only for a period of time corresponding to the required fire-resistance rating of an exterior nonbearing wall with the same fire separation distance, and in a building of the same group. Where the fire-resistance rating determined in accordance with this exception exceeds the fire-resistance rating determined in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263, the fire exposure time period, water pressure and application duration criteria for the hose stream test of ASTM E119 or UL 263 shall be based on the fire-resistance rating determined in accordance with this section.

The application of any of the methods listed in this section shall be based on the fire exposure and acceptance criteria specified in ASTM E119 or UL 263. The required fire resistance of a building element, component or assembly shall be permitted to be established by any of the following methods or procedures:
  1. Fire-resistance designs documented in approved sources.
  2. Prescriptive designs of fire-resistance-rated building elements, components or assemblies as prescribed in Section 721.
  3. Calculations in accordance with Section 722.
  4. Engineering analysis based on a comparison of building element, component or assemblies designs having fire-resistance ratings as determined by the test procedures set forth in ASTM E119 or UL 263.
  5. Alternative protection methods as allowed by Section 104.11.
  6. Fire-resistance designs certified by an approved agency.

diagrams.title: Two-Family Dwelling Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Dwelling Unit: A single unit providing complete independent living facilities for one or more persons, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation.

Draft Stop: A material, device or construction installed to restrict the movement of air within open spaces of concealed areas of building components such as crawl spaces, floor-ceiling assemblies, roof-ceiling assemblies and attics.

Two dwelling units can be structures known as "duplexes" or ADU's (Accessory Dwelling Units in some jurisdictions. When altering an existing residence to create a second unit, attention should be paid to the continuity of the dwelling separation between the existing dwelling and the new dwelling. This could require unexpected work to be required in the crawlspace (if present) or in the attic.

In certain jurisdictions, two family dwellings may be governed by either the Building Code or Residential Code (but provisions may not be mixed). In the Building Code, similar wall and floor separations are known as Fire Partitions (Section 708) and Horizontal Assemblies (Section 711). See also Section 420 for additional building code requirements.

diagrams.title: Fire Rating at Prop. Line
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The residential code requires exterior walls at property lines to have either proper separation or fire-resistant construction. The distances of the requirements depend on whether the structure is protected by an automatic fire sprinkler system. When required, the wall assembly is required to have been tested for fire exposure from either side (inside or outside) to provide protection not only to the structure from a fire in an adjacent lot, but also to protect the adjacent lot from a fire within the structure.

children.body: Under the prescriptive fire-resistance requirements of this code, the fire-resistance rating of a building element, component or assembly shall be established without the use of automatic sprinklers or any other fire suppression system being incorporated as part of the assembly tested in accordance with the fire exposure, procedures and acceptance criteria specified in ASTM E119 or UL 263. However, this section shall not prohibit or limit the duties and powers of the building official allowed by Sections 104.10 and 104.11.

The tests indicated in Sections 703.5.1 and 703.5.2 shall serve as criteria for acceptance of building materials as set forth in Sections 602.2, 602.3 and 602.4 in Type I, II, III and IV construction. The term "noncombustible" does not apply to the flame spread characteristics of interior finish or trim materials. A material shall not be classified as a noncombustible building construction material if it is subject to an increase in combustibility or flame spread beyond the limitations herein established through the effects of age, moisture or other atmospheric conditions.
Materials required to be noncombustible shall be tested in accordance with ASTM E136.

Materials having a structural base of noncombustible material as determined in accordance with Section 703.5.1 with a surfacing not more than 0.125 inch (3.18 mm) thick that has a flame spread index not greater than 50 when tested in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723 shall be acceptable as noncombustible materials.

Fire-resistance-rated glazing, when tested in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263 and complying with the requirements of Section 707, shall be permitted. Fire-resistance-rated glazing shall bear a label marked in accordance with Table 716.3 issued by an agency and shall be permanently identified on the glazing.

diagrams.title: Fire Protective vs. Fire Resistive Glazing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Diagram adapted from SaftiFirst product literature.

children.body:
Where there is an accessible concealed floor, floor-ceiling or attic space, fire walls, fire barriers, fire partitions, smoke barriers and smoke partitions or any other wall required to have protected openings or penetrations shall be effectively and permanently identified with signs or stenciling in the concealed space. Such identification shall:
  1. Be located within 15 feet (4572 mm) of the end of each wall and at intervals not exceeding 30 feet (9144 mm) measured horizontally along the wall or partition.
  2. Include lettering not less than 3 inches (76 mm) in height with a minimum 3/8-inch (9.5 mm) stroke in a contrasting color incorporating the suggested wording, "FIRE AND/OR SMOKE BARRIER—PROTECT ALL OPENINGS," or other wording.

diagrams.title: Marking of Fire Rated Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In older buildings, fire-rated walls are harder to spot for an electrician installing boxes or running cables and conduits. Only someone familiar with wall construction and occupancy types will know which walls of an older building are required to be fire-resistance rated. The required markings let those installing future work know that fire-rated penetrations and openings require special consideration so that an unsafe condition is not created by not providing proper fire-rated construction for openings and penetrations.

Verify the exact wording required for your jurisdiction. Note that wording required by the Life Safety Code, if adopted, requires that the type of fire-resistive assembly be identified, whereas the Building Code provides suggested wording. Older versions of the Life Safety Code, such as that required by CMS doesn't appear to have the same requirement.

diagrams.title: Individual vs. Membrane Protection of Steel Beams
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where the fire-resistance rating of structural members based on construction type is required by table 601, primary steel beams must be protected by individual encasement on all sides. Secondary members associated with floor and roof assemblies may be protected by individual encasement or membrane protection.

diagrams.title: Exterior Structural Member Fire Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior load-bearing structural members located within exterior walls or outside a building must have the highest fire-resistance rating as determined by structural element and construction type per table 601or fire separation distance per table 602 whichever is highest.

diagrams.title: Structural Member Protection At High Ceilings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to Table 601, Footnote b, except in Group F-1, H, M and S-1 occupancies, fire protection of structural members in roof construction shall not be required, including protection of primary structural frame members, roof framing and decking where every part of the roof construction is 20 feet or more above any floor immediately below. Fire-retardant-treated wood members shall be allowed to be used for such unprotected members. However, be aware the 2015 codes does not include the term "primary structural frame members".

UpCodes Note: Primary structural members include columns per the definition. However, per an interpretation on June 22, 2018, regarding the 2018 codes, ICC staff opined that the columns were not part of the fire rating exemption provided by Table 601, footnote b. Per Section 704, if columns are required to be fire rated, the protection is required to extend to its connection with other structural members. Please check with your local AHJ concerning the interpretation of this issue in your locality.

diagrams.title: Steel Floor / Roof with Metal Deck: Example 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Composite steel and concrete deck construction has steel decking spanning between steel beams. These steel beams have welded studs that create an interface with the concrete. This causes the steel beam and the steel deck to structurally operate as a single system, similar to a T-beam concrete beam/slab system. The concrete may have embedded rebar for masonry parapets or embeds for things such as bracing or suspended ceiling systems. Coordination with the Structural Engineer of Record is necessary to ensure the proper assembly is selected to provide the proper fire ratings. In addition, Sprayed Fire-Resistant Materials may be required on the underside of the deck to provide the requisite resistance rating.

diagrams.title: Steel Floor / Roof with Metal Deck: Example
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Composite steel and concrete deck construction has steel decking spanning between steel beams. These steel beams have welded studs that create an interface with the concrete. This causes the steel beam and the steel deck to structurally operate as a single system, similar to a T-beam concrete beam/slab system. The concrete may have embedded rebar for masonry parapets or embeds for things such as bracing or suspended ceiling systems. Coordination with the Structural Engineer of Record is necessary to ensure the proper assembly is selected to provide the proper fire ratings. In addition, Sprayed Fire-Resistant Materials may be required on the underside of the deck to provide the requisite resistance rating.

children.displayTitle: Section 704 Fire-Resistance Rating of Structural Members

children.body:
The fire-resistance ratings of structural members and assemblies shall comply with this section and the requirements for the type of construction as specified in Table 601. The fire-resistance ratings shall be not less than the ratings required for the fire-resistance-rated assemblies supported by the structural members.
Exception: Fire barriers, fire partitions, smoke barriers and horizontal assemblies as provided in Sections 707.5, 708.4, 709.4 and 711.2, respectively.

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours. Per 704.1 any structure supporting the first floor assembly would likewise also need to have the same 1-1/2 hour fire protection rating.

children.body: Where columns are required to have protection to achieve a fire-resistance rating, the entire column shall be provided individual encasement protection by protecting it on all sides for the full column height, including connections to other structural members, with materials having the required fire-resistance rating. Where the column extends through a ceiling, the encasement protection shall be continuous from the top of the foundation or floor/ceiling assembly below through the ceiling space to the top of the column.

Members of the primary structural frame other than columns that are required to have protection to achieve a fire-resistance rating and support more than two floors or one floor and roof, or support a load-bearing wall or a nonload-bearing wall more than two stories high, shall be provided individual encasement protection by protecting them on all sides for the full length, including connections to other structural members, with materials having the required fire-resistance rating.
Exception: Individual encasement protection on all sides shall be permitted on all exposed sides provided the extent of protection is in accordance with the required fire-resistance rating, as determined in Section 703.

diagrams.title: Individual vs. Membrane Protection of Steel Beams
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where the fire-resistance rating of structural members based on construction type is required by table 601, primary steel beams must be protected by individual encasement on all sides. Secondary members associated with floor and roof assemblies may be protected by individual encasement or membrane protection.

children.displayTitle: 704.3 Protection of the Primary Structural Frame Other Than Columns
children.titleText: Protection of the Primary Structural Frame Other Than Columns

children.body: Secondary members that are required to have protection to achieve a fire-resistance rating shall be protected by individual encasement protection.

diagrams.title: Example: Shaft Wall at Secondary Member
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The example shown is one way of ensuring that a joint between an intermediate tube steel beam, such as might be found in a shaft, elevator shaft or stair enclosure could be treated to ensure protection of the steel member and continuity of the shaft wall. This assumes the member is a secondary framing member, and not a primary structural member framing into a column. The joints between the shaft wall and the other material is required to be detailed per the requirements for joint systems and an approved assembly be used. Source: hcai.ca.gov. OPD No. FR3.08

children.body: Studs and boundary elements that are integral elements in load-bearing walls of light-frame construction shall be permitted to have required fire-resistance ratings provided by the membrane protection provided for the load-bearing wall.

Horizontal assemblies are permitted to be protected with a membrane or ceiling where the membrane or ceiling provides the required fire-resistance rating and is installed in accordance with Section 711.

The required thickness and construction of fire-resistance-rated assemblies enclosing trusses shall be based on the results of full-scale tests or combinations of tests on truss components or on approved calculations based on such tests that satisfactorily demonstrate that the assembly has the required fire resistance.
The edges of lugs, brackets, rivets and bolt heads attached to structural members shall be permitted to extend to within 1 inch (25 mm) of the surface of the fire protection.

Thickness of protection for concrete or masonry reinforcement shall be measured to the outside of the reinforcement except that stirrups and spiral reinforcement ties are permitted to project not more than 0.5-inch (12.7 mm) into the protection.
Pipes, wires, conduits, ducts or other service facilities shall not be embedded in the required fire protective covering of a structural member that is required to be individually encased.

Where the fire protective covering of a structural member is subject to impact damage from moving vehicles, the handling of merchandise or other activity, the fire protective covering shall be protected by corner guards or by a substantial jacket of metal or other noncombustible material to a height adequate to provide full protection, but not less than 5 feet (1524 mm) from the finished floor.
Exception: Corner protection is not required on concrete columns in open or enclosed parking garages.

Load-bearing structural members located within the exterior walls or on the outside of a building or structure shall be provided with the highest fire-resistance rating as determined in accordance with the following:
  1. As required by Table 601 for the type of building element based on the type of construction of the building;
  2. As required by Table 601 for exterior bearing walls based on the type of construction; and
  3. As required by Table 602 for exterior walls based on the fire separation distance.

diagrams.title: Exterior Structural Member Fire Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior load-bearing structural members located within exterior walls or outside a building must have the highest fire-resistance rating as determined by structural element and construction type per table 601or fire separation distance per table 602 whichever is highest.

children.body: Fire protection is not required at the bottom flange of lintels, shelf angles and plates, spanning not more than 6 feet 4 inches (1931 mm) whether part of the primary structural frame or not, and from the bottom flange of lintels, shelf angles and plates not part of the structural frame, regardless of span.

Fire-resistance ratings for the isolation system shall meet the fire-resistance rating required for the columns, walls or other structural elements in which the isolation system is installed in accordance with Table 601. Isolation systems required to have a fire-resistance rating shall be protected with approved materials or construction assemblies designed to provide the same degree of fire resistance as the structural element in which the system is installed when tested in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263 (see Section 703.2).

Such isolation system protection applied to isolator units shall be capable of retarding the transfer of heat to the isolator unit in such a manner that the required gravity load-carrying capacity of the isolator unit will not be impaired after exposure to the standard time-temperature curve fire test prescribed in ASTM E119 or UL 263 for a duration not less than that required for the fire-resistance rating of the structure element in which the system is installed.

Such isolation system protection applied to isolator units shall be suitably designed and securely installed so as not to dislodge, loosen, sustain damage or otherwise impair its ability to accommodate the seismic movements for which the isolator unit is designed and to maintain its integrity for the purpose of providing the required fire-resistance protection.
Sprayed fire-resistant materials (SFRM) shall comply with Sections 704.13.1 through 704.13.5.

diagrams.title: Example: End Joint - 1hr rated wall at SFRM
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This is an example of a fire rated face joint between a 1-hour rated fire partition or fire barrier, and a steel column with sprayed fire-resistant material (SFRM). Materials used should be consistent with the listed assembly chosen (UL, etc.). source: oshpd.ca.gov. OPD No. FR1.02

diagrams.descriptionHtml: This is an example of a fire rated face joint between a 1-hour rated fire partition or fire barrier, and a steel column with sprayed fire-resistant material (SFRM). Materials used should be consistent with the listed assembly chosen (UL, etc.). source: oshpd.ca.gov. OPD No. FR1.01

diagrams.descriptionHtml: This is an example of a fire rated joint between a 1-hour rated fire partition or fire barrier, and a steel column with sprayed fire-resistant material (SFRM). Materials used should be consistent with the listed assembly chosen (UL, etc.). Source: oshpd.ca.gov. OPD No. FR1.00

diagrams.title: Example: Shaft Wall at Secondary Member
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The example shown is one way of ensuring that a joint between an intermediate tube steel beam, such as might be found in a shaft, elevator shaft or stair enclosure could be treated to ensure protection of the steel member and continuity of the shaft wall. This assumes the member is a secondary framing member, and not a primary structural member framing into a column. The joints between the shaft wall and the other material is required to be detailed per the requirements for joint systems and an approved assembly be used. Source: hcai.ca.gov. OPD No. FR3.08

diagrams.descriptionHtml: Source: oshpd.ca.gov. OPD No. 1.16

diagrams.descriptionHtml: source: oshpd.ca.gov. OPD No: FR1.10

children.body: The application of SFRM shall be consistent with the fire-resistance rating and the listing, including, but not limited to, minimum thickness and dry density of the applied SFRM, method of application, substrate surface conditions and the use of bonding adhesives, sealants, reinforcing or other materials.

The application of SFRM shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions. The instructions shall include, but are not limited to, substrate temperatures and surface conditions and SFRM handling, storage, mixing, conveyance, method of application, curing and ventilation.
The SFRM shall be applied to a substrate in compliance with Sections 704.13.3.1 through 704.13.3.2.

Substrates to receive SFRM shall be free of dirt, oil, grease, release agents, loose scale and any other condition that prevents adhesion. The substrates shall be free of primers, paints and encapsulants other than those fire tested and listed by a nationally recognized testing agency. Primed, painted or encapsulated steel shall be allowed, provided that testing has demonstrated that required adhesion is maintained.

Where the SFRM is to be applied over primers, paints or encapsulants other than those specified in the listing, the material shall be field tested in accordance with ASTM E736. Where testing of the SFRM with primers, paints or encapsulants demonstrates that required adhesion is maintained, SFRM shall be permitted to be applied to primed, painted or encapsulated wide flange steel shapes in accordance with the following conditions:
  1. The beam flange width does not exceed 12 inches (305 mm); or
  2. The column flange width does not exceed 16 inches (400 mm); or
  3. The beam or column web depth does not exceed 16 inches (400 mm).
  4. The average and minimum bond strength values shall be determined based on a minimum of five bond tests conducted in accordance with ASTM E736. Bond tests conducted in accordance with ASTM E736 shall indicate an average bond strength of not less than 80 percent and an individual bond strength of not less than 50 percent, when compared to the bond strength of the SFRM as applied to clean uncoated 1/8-inch-thick (3.2 mm) steel plate.

A minimum ambient and substrate temperature of 40°F (4.44°C) shall be maintained during and for not fewer than 24 hours after the application of the SFRM, unless the manufacturer's instructions allow otherwise.

The finished condition of SFRM applied to structural members or assemblies shall not, upon complete drying or curing, exhibit cracks, voids, spalls, delamination or any exposure of the substrate. Surface irregularities of SFRM shall be deemed acceptable.

diagrams.title: Interior Stair & Ramp Exterior Wall Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The exterior walls of interior exit stairway enclosures only need to meet the typical exterior wall requirements for the building based on its fire separation distance as defined in section 705. Where the exit stairway exterior wall is non-rated or has unprotected openings and the angle between the adjacent wall and the exterior wall of the exit stairway is less than 180 degrees, the first 10' of the immediately adjacent wall is required to have a fire-resistance rating of 1 hour or more and 3/4 hour opening protection. The fire-rated wall and opening protection needs to be provided vertically from the ground up to 10' above the top floor landing or the roof line, whichever is lower. If the exterior wall of the exit stairway is rated and its openings are protected the wall immediately adjacent to the exit stairway may be constructed based on the fire separation distance per section 705.

diagrams.title: Vapor Retarders for Exterior Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In all cases where a vapor retarder is required, the location is at the interior side of the framing. The designer needs to be aware of the climate zone (see chapter 3 of the energy code), and the exterior wall siding and insulation systems to determine what class of vapor barrier is required. Section 1404 defines where and what type of vapor barrier is required. Class I and II vapor barriers are not allowed in climate zones 1 and 2 or where class II vapor barriers are required. Class I vapor barriers are also not allowed in in climate zones 3 and 4 other than Marine 4. Class I and II vapor barriers are required in climate zones 4 Marine, 5, 6, 7, and 8 unless a class III vapor barrier is required. When the building will have a continuous foam plastic layer of exterior insulation it will likely need a class III vapor barrier. The designer will need to know the siding system and R value of the foam insulation and apply that information to table 1404.3.2 to determine if a class III vapor barrier is required. Table 1404.3.2 references vented cladding which is somewhat defined in 1404.3.4 and would likely include rainscreen assemblies. The need for a class III vapor barrier is not climate zone dependent.

diagrams.title: Stair Enclosures at Exterior Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairway enclousure walls are intended to provide a specific hourly fire resistance from a fire occurring within the same building. Therefore they are required for adjoining interior walls, but not necessarily exterior walls. However, if the walls are near to a property line fire-separation distance datum line, then the building itself, which includes the stairway, must still be protected from outside hazards as an exterior wall of a building would. Keep in mind that stairways also have an occupancy group, and that occupancy group is required to determine the required exterior wall fire rating.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

diagrams.title: Fire Ratings at Prop. Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior walls that have a variable distance to the property lines may have fire ratings that change across the length of wall. Also affecting the fire rating is the occupancy group adjacent to the exterior wall. Fire separation distances are measured at right angles from the face of the wall.

diagrams.title: Ext. Walls of Int. Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior walls of interior exit stairs and ramps aren't always required to meet a fire resistance rating. Section 1023.7 requires protection against fire exposure to non-rated walls of interior exit stair/ramp enclosures. Protection must be provided for building walls exposing the stair/ramp wall within 180 degrees. A minimum 1-hour fire rating is required within 10 feet of the exit wall. The designer has the option of meeting the fire rating either at the stair/ramp wall, or the building wall causing the exposure. Openings in the required protection distance of 10 feet shall be minimum 3/4 hour rated.

diagrams.title: Vertical Separation of Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
If openings in adjacent stories are within 5 horizontal feet of one another, and the opening in the lower story has a fire protection rating of less than 3/4 hour, the openings must be separated vertically by at least 3 feet by spandrel girders, exterior walls or other similar assemblies that have a minimum fire-resistance rating of 1 hour. The spandrel area needs to be rated for exposure to fire from both the interior and exterior. Another acceptable opening separation is a flame barrier. The barrier must project a minimum or 30" and be of 1 hr minimum fire-resistance rating.

Exceptions:
  1. This section does not apply to buildings that are three stories or less above grade plane.
  2. This section does not apply to buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  3. This section does not apply to open parking garages.

diagrams.title: Anchor Buildings and Mall Fire Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Mall anchor buildings are to be separated from a mall building by fire walls in compliance with section 706. Where the anchor building is 3 or less stories above grade plane and the same occupancy as the mall tenant spaces a 2 hour rated fire barrier may be used in place of the fire walls. Where an anchor building is separated from an open mall building with an open mall the exterior walls of the anchor building need to comply with the requirements of table 705.5.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Exterior Walls (IBC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At a minimum, the exterior wall of an exit passageway must comply with section 705, which defines how exterior walls may be constructed in relation to the design fire separation distance. When the exterior wall of an exit passageway is fire rated and openings within the wall are protected no additional measures are required on the exterior walls within 10' of the passageway beyond what section 705 calls for. When the exterior wall of an exit passageway is nonrated and openings within the wall are unprotected no additional measures are required on the exterior of the building provided the exit passageway exterior wall aligns with or is proud of (in front of) all adjacent exterior walls within 10' horizontally of the exit passageway exterior wall. When the exterior wall of an exit passageway is nonrated or has unprotected opening and an adjacent exterior wall meets the passageway wall at an angle of less than 180 degrees, such that the adjacent wall within 10' of the passageway wall is proud of the passageway wall, the adjacent wall shall be 1 hour fire-resistance rated within 10' of the passageway and openings within the same 10' of the adjacent wall shall have a 3/4 hour fire-protection rating. The fire-resistant construction and opening protections where required within 10' of the passageway must extend from the ground to 10' above the passageway floor or the roof line, whichever is lower.

diagrams.title: Bay and Oriel Windows
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Bay and Oriel Windows are considered to be wall projections by the building code. All projections must comply with the minimum distance from the fire separation line as defined in Table 705.2. Bay and Oriel window construction when of combustible material need to conform to the same requirements as would be required for the exterior wall from which it projects from. The buildings exterior wall requirements are typically based on Table 705.5 and depend on the buildings occupancy group, construction type and fire separation distance.

children.body: Exterior walls shall comply with this section.

Cornices, eave overhangs, exterior balconies and similar projections extending beyond the exterior wall shall conform to the requirements of this section and Section 1406. Exterior egress balconies and exterior exit stairways and ramps shall comply with Sections 1021 and 1027, respectively. Projections shall not extend any closer to the line used to determine the fire separation distance than shown in Table 705.2.
Exception: Buildings on the same lot and considered as portions of one building in accordance with Section 705.3 are not required to comply with this section for projections between the buildings.

TABLE 705.2
MINIMUM DISTANCE OF PROJECTION
FIRE SEPARATION DISTANCE (FSD) MINIMUM DISTANCE FROM LINE USED TO DETERMINE FSD
0 feet to 2 feet Projections not permitted
Greater than 2 feet to 3 feet 24 inches
Greater than 3 feet to less than 30 feet 24 inches plus 8 inches for every foot of FSD beyond 3 feet or fraction thereof
30 feet or greater 20 feet
For SI: 1 foot = 304.8 mm; 1 inch = 25.4 mm.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections (Excpt. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

T
he code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

children.body: Projections from walls of Type I or II construction shall be of noncombustible materials or combustible materials as allowed by Sections 1406.3 and 1406.4.
Projections from walls of Type III, IV or V construction shall be of any approved material.
children.displayTitle: 705.2.2 Type III, IV or V Construction
children.titleText: Type III, IV or V Construction

children.body:
Combustible projections extending to within 5 feet (1524 mm) of the line used to determine the fire separation distance shall be of not less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction, Type IV construction, fire-retardant-treated wood or as required by Section 1406.3.
Exception: Type VB construction shall be allowed for combustible projections in Group R-3 and U occupancies with a fire separation distance greater than or equal to 5 feet (1524 mm).

diagrams.title: Combustible Projection Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A fire near a building projection will cause the heat of a fire to be trapped and has a greater chance of a building fire occurring than if it were a vertical exterior wall without a projection. Therefore, special consideration is required to be given to combustible projections.

children.body:
For the purposes of determining the required wall and opening protection, projections and roof-covering requirements, buildings on the same lot shall be assumed to have an imaginary line between them.

Where a new building is to be erected on the same lot as an existing building, the location of the assumed imaginary line with relation to the existing building shall be such that the exterior wall and opening protection of the existing building meet the criteria as set forth in Sections 705.5 and 705.8.
Exceptions:
  1. Two or more buildings on the same lot shall be either regulated as separate buildings or shall be considered as portions of one building if the aggregate area of such buildings is within the limits specified in Chapter 5 for a single building. Where the buildings contain different occupancy groups or are of different types of construction, the area shall be that allowed for the most restrictive occupancy or construction.
  2. Where an S-2 parking garage of Construction Type I or IIA is erected on the same lot as a Group R-2 building, and there is no fire separation distance between these buildings, then the adjoining exterior walls between the buildings are permitted to have occupant use openings in accordance with Section 706.8. However, opening protectives in such openings shall only be required in the exterior wall of the S-2 parking garage, not in the exterior wall openings in the R-2 building, and these opening protectives in the exterior wall of the S-2 parking garage shall be not less than 11/2-hour fire protection rating.

diagrams.title: Buildings on Same Lot: Vertical Exposure
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Buildings on the same lot but that are of different heights may require protection of the upper windows against fire that could be coming from a fire at the adjacent lower building. This code section does not address a requirement for the wall itself to be fire rated, but the opening to have protection. Table 602 would govern the required fire rating based on the fire-separation distance. However, if the wall between the buildings is a fire wall, then 706.6.1 would apply, which requires a fire rating of the 15 feet that extend beyond the lower building.

diagrams.title: Fire Separation Distance: Group H
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The H-1, H-2 and H-3 Occupancies are reserved for buildings having hazardous materials quantities that increase the risk of explosion and/or high intensity fires. Minimum fire separation distances are established to mitigate the impact a fire event will have on adjacent buildings. Fire Separation Distance is measured between the Lot Line and outside face of wall enclosing the H Occupancy. Additional separation may be specified by the Fire Code and referenced standards to address material specific hazard of product used or stored.

diagrams.title: Buildings on the Same Lot - Excpt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 addresses the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already has a building on it. One has to have an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines to apply the section correctly. To comply with the base condition the designer needs to establish a fire separation line on the site that is in compliance with the existing buildings exterior wall and opening protectives. Once that line is located the new building may be designed as if the newly established line is a property line. Exception 1 allows for the new building and existing buildings to be considered one structure and eliminates the fire separation protectives required by the imaginary fire separation line of the base condition.

Exception 1 applies limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type on the site.

Exception 2 only applies when an S-2 parking garage of type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. Zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage is required for the exception. 1-1/2 hr fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts with the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with 706.8 which limits single opening size and aggregate width of openings relative the wall length.

diagrams.title: Buildings on the Same Lot (Ex. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 outlines the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already contains an existing building. To apply this section correctly, an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines is necessary. The designer must establish a fire separation line on the site that aligns with the exterior wall and opening protectives of the existing building. Once this line is defined, the new building can be designed as if this line is a property line. Exception 1 permits the new and existing buildings to be treated as a single structure, thereby eliminating the fire separation protections required by the imaginary fire separation line in the base condition.

Exception 1 limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type present on the site.

Exception 2 applies when an S-2 parking garage of Type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. This exception allows for zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage. However, 1-1/2 hour fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with Section 706.8, which limits the size of single openings and the total width of openings relative to the wall length.

diagrams.title: Buildings on the Same Lot
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 addresses the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already has a building on it. One has to have an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines to apply the section correctly. To comply with the base condition the designer needs to establish a fire separation line on the site that is in compliance with the existing buildings exterior wall and opening protectives. Once that line is located the new building may be designed as if the newly established line is a property line. Exception 1 allows for the new building and existing buildings to be considered one structure and eliminates the fire separation protectives required by the imaginary fire separation line of the base condition.

Exception 1 applies limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type on the site.

Exception 2 only applies when an S-2 parking garage of type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. Zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage is required for the exception. 1-1/2 hr fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts with the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with 706.8 which limits single opening size and aggregate width of openings relative the wall length.

children.body: Exterior walls shall be of materials permitted by the building type of construction.

diagrams.title: Combustibles on Non-Combustible Ext. Walls: Limitations
Wood Veneer on Non-Combustible Wall Construction
Combustible Water Resistive Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a building is over 40" tall above grade plane, is of types I, II, II or IV construction and is greater than 40' tall above grade plane, if the water-resistive barrier (WRB) is combustible it must be tested and comply with the criteria of NFPA 285. Combustibility of the WRB is determined by section 703.3. Fenestrations, and flashings are not considered part of the WRB in determining where a combustible WRB is permitted. The Code allows for a combustible WRB without NFPA 285 compliance where the WRB is the only combustible wall component and the siding is brick, concrete, stone, terra cotta, stucco or steel with minimum thicknesses in accordance with Table 1404.2. The Code also allows for a combustible WRB without NFPA 285 compliance where the WRB is the only combustible wall component and has the following characteristics: Flame spread index ≤25, smoke-developed index ≤450, peak heat release rate <150 kW/m2, total heat release of less than 20 MJ/m2, and an effective heat of combustion of less than 18 MJ/kg.

children.body: Exterior walls shall be fire-resistance rated in accordance with Tables 601 and 602 and this section. The required fire-resistance rating of exterior walls with a fire separation distance of greater than 10 feet (3048 mm) shall be rated for exposure to fire from the inside. The required fire-resistance rating of exterior walls with a fire separation distance of less than or equal to 10 feet (3048 mm) shall be rated for exposure to fire from both sides.

diagrams.title: Stair Enclosures at Exterior Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairway enclousure walls are intended to provide a specific hourly fire resistance from a fire occurring within the same building. Therefore they are required for adjoining interior walls, but not necessarily exterior walls. However, if the walls are near to a property line fire-separation distance datum line, then the building itself, which includes the stairway, must still be protected from outside hazards as an exterior wall of a building would. Keep in mind that stairways also have an occupancy group, and that occupancy group is required to determine the required exterior wall fire rating.

diagrams.title: Type IIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIA ("Two-A") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "A" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are required to be fire-rated construction.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Type IIB Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIB ("Two-B") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "B" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are not required to be fire-rated construction. Exceptions may exist, such as walls close to a property line or a neighboring building.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Fire Ratings at Prop. Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior walls that have a variable distance to the property lines may have fire ratings that change across the length of wall. Also affecting the fire rating is the occupancy group adjacent to the exterior wall. Fire separation distances are measured at right angles from the face of the wall.

diagrams.title: Openings In Ext. Walls at Lot Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum area of unprotected and protected openings permitted in an exterior wall in any story of a building shall not exceed the percentages specified in Table 705.8 based on the fire separation distance of each individual story.

diagrams.title: Buildings on the Same Lot - Excpt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml:

Once that line is located the new building may be designed as if the newly established line is a property line. Exception 1 allows for the new building and existing buildings to be considered one structure and eliminates the fire separation protectives required by the imaginary fire separation line of the base condition.

Exception 2 only applies when an S-2 parking garage of type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. Zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage is required for the exception. 1-1/2 hr fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts with the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with 706.8 which limits single opening size and aggregate width of openings relative the wall length.

Where the anchor building is 3 or less stories above grade plane and the same occupancy as the mall tenant spaces a 2 hour rated fire barrier may be used in place of the fire walls. Where an anchor building is separated from an open mall building with an open mall the exterior walls of the anchor building need to comply with the requirements of table 705.5.

diagrams.title: Bay and Oriel Windows
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Bay and Oriel Windows are considered to be wall projections by the building code. All projections must comply with the minimum distance from the fire separation line as defined in Table 705.2. Bay and Oriel window construction when of combustible material need to conform to the same requirements as would be required for the exterior wall from which it projects from. children.body: Exterior walls shall extend to the height required by Section 705.11. Interior structural elements that brace the exterior wall but that are not located within the plane of the exterior wall shall have the minimum fire-resistance rating required in Table 601 for that structural element. Structural elements that brace the exterior wall but are located outside of the exterior wall or within the plane of the exterior wall shall have the minimum fire-resistance rating required in Tables 601 and 602 for the exterior wall.

Where protected openings are not limited by Section 705.8, the limitation on the rise of temperature on the unexposed surface of exterior walls as required by ASTM E119 or UL 263 shall not apply. Where protected openings are limited by Section 705.8, the limitation on the rise of temperature on the unexposed surface of exterior walls as required by ASTM E119 or UL 263 shall not apply provided that a correction is made for radiation from the unexposed exterior wall surface in accordance with the following formula:

(Equation 7-1)

where:
Ae = Equivalent area of protected openings.
A = Actual area of protected openings.
Af = Area of exterior wall surface in the story under consideration exclusive of openings, on which the temperature limitations of ASTM E119 or UL 263 for walls are exceeded.
Feo = An "equivalent opening factor" derived from Figure 705.7 based on the average temperature of the unexposed wall surface and the fire-resistance rating of the wall.

Openings in exterior walls shall comply with Sections 705.8.1 through 705.8.7.

TABLE 705.8
MAXIMUM AREA OF EXTERIOR WALL OPENINGS BASED ON FIRE SEPARATION DISTANCE AND DEGREE OF OPENING PROTECTION

For SI: 1 foot = 304.8 mm.

UP, NS = Unprotected openings in buildings not equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.

UP, S = Unprotected openings in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.

P = Openings protected with an opening protective assembly in accordance with Section 705.8.2.
  1. Values indicated are the percentage of the area of the exterior wall, per story.
  2. For the requirements for fire walls of buildings with differing heights, see Section 706.6.1.
  3. For openings in a fire wall for buildings on the same lot, see Section 706.8.
  4. The maximum percentage of unprotected and protected openings shall be 25 percent for Group R-3 occupancies.
  5. Unprotected openings shall not be permitted for openings with a fire separation distance of less than 15 feet for Group H-2 and H-3 occupancies.
  6. The area of unprotected and protected openings shall not be limited for Group R-3 occupancies, with a fire separation distance of 5 feet or greater.
  7. The area of openings in an open parking structure with a fire separation distance of 10 feet or greater shall not be limited.
  8. Includes buildings accessory to Group R-3.
  9. Not applicable to Group H-1, H-2 and H-3 occupancies.
  10. The area of openings in a building containing only a Group U occupancy private garage or carport with a fire separation distance of 5 feet (1523 mm) or greater shall not be limited.
  11. For openings between S-2 parking garage and Group R-2 building, see Section 705.3, Exception 2.

diagrams.title: Openings In Ext. Walls at Lot Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum area of unprotected and protected openings permitted in an exterior wall in any story of a building shall not exceed the percentages specified in Table 705.8 based on the fire separation distance of each individual story.
