Exception 1 applies limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type on the site.

Exception 2 only applies when an S-2 parking garage of type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. Zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage is required for the exception. 1-1/2 hr fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts with the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with 706.8 which limits single opening size and aggregate width of openings relative the wall length.

diagrams.title: Air Intake Opening Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Air intake openings provide a way for outdoor air to enter a building and supply fresh air to its occupants. The ventilation can occur from either natural or mechanical ventilation.
When the intake air or exhaust system is not properly designed, contaminated air has the possibility of entering the building which would reduce the indoor air quality and potentially cause unwanted odors or even potential health issues for the buildings occupants.

diagrams.title: Bay and Oriel Windows
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Bay and Oriel Windows are considered to be wall projections by the building code. All projections must comply with the minimum distance from the fire separation line as defined in Table 705.2. Bay and Oriel window construction when of combustible material need to conform to the same requirements as would be required for the exterior wall from which it projects from. The buildings exterior wall requirements are typically based on Table 705.5 and depend on the buildings occupancy group, construction type and fire separation distance.

children.body:
The maximum area of unprotected and protected openings permitted in an exterior wall in any story of a building shall not exceed the percentages specified in Table 705.8.
Exceptions:
  1. Openings permitted by Section 705.8.7.
  2. In other than Group H occupancies, unlimited unprotected openings are permitted in the first story above grade plane either:
    1. Where the wall faces a street and has a fire separation distance of more than 15 feet (4572 mm).
    2. Where the wall faces an unoccupied space. The unoccupied space shall be on the same lot or dedicated for public use, shall not be less than 30 feet (9144 mm) in width and shall have access from a street via a posted fire lane in accordance with the Fire Code.
  3. Buildings, whose exterior bearing walls, exterior nonbearing walls, and exterior primary structural frame are not required to be fire-resistance rated and shall be permitted to have unlimited unprotected openings.

diagrams.title: Openings In Ext. Walls at Lot Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum area of unprotected and protected openings permitted in an exterior wall in any story of a building shall not exceed the percentages specified in Table 705.8 based on the fire separation distance of each individual story.

children.body:
Where openings are required to be protected, fire doors and fire shutters shall comply with Section 716.5 and fire window assemblies shall comply with Section 716.6.
Exception: Opening protectives are not required where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 and the exterior openings are protected by a water curtain using automatic sprinklers approved for that use.

diagrams.title: Openings In Ext. Walls at Lot Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum area of unprotected and protected openings permitted in an exterior wall in any story of a building shall not exceed the percentages specified in Table 705.8 based on the fire separation distance of each individual story.

diagrams.title: Fire Protective vs. Fire Resistive Glazing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Diagram adapted from SaftiFirst product literature.

children.body: Where unprotected openings are permitted, windows and doors shall be constructed of any approved materials. Glazing shall conform to the requirements of Chapters 24 and 26.

diagrams.title: Openings In Ext. Walls at Lot Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum area of unprotected and protected openings permitted in an exterior wall in any story of a building shall not exceed the percentages specified in Table 705.8 based on the fire separation distance of each individual story.

diagrams.title: Vertical Separation of Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
If openings in adjacent stories are within 5 horizontal feet of one another, and the opening in the lower story has a fire protection rating of less than 3/4 hour, the openings must be separated vertically by at least 3 feet by spandrel girders, exterior walls or other similar assemblies that have a minimum fire-resistance rating of 1 hour. The spandrel area needs to be rated for exposure to fire from both the interior and exterior. Another acceptable opening separation is a flame barrier. The barrier must project a minimum or 30" and be of 1 hr minimum fire-resistance rating.

Exceptions:
  1. This section does not apply to buildings that are three stories or less above grade plane.
  2. This section does not apply to buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  3. This section does not apply to open parking garages.

children.body:
Where both unprotected and protected openings are located in the exterior wall in any story of a building, the total area of openings shall be determined in accordance with the following:

(Equation 7-2)

where:
Ap = Actual area of protected openings, or the equivalent area of protected openings, Ae (see Section 705.7).
ap = Allowable area of protected openings.
Au = Actual area of unprotected openings.
au = Allowable area of unprotected openings.

Openings in exterior walls in adjacent stories shall be separated vertically to protect against fire spread on the exterior of the buildings where the openings are within 5 feet (1524 mm) of each other horizontally and the opening in the lower story is not a protected opening with a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour. Such openings shall be separated vertically not less than 3 feet (914 mm) by spandrel girders, exterior walls or other similar assemblies that have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour, rated for exposure to fire from both sides, or by flame barriers that extend horizontally not less than 30 inches (762 mm) beyond the exterior wall. Flame barriers shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour. The unexposed surface temperature limitations specified in ASTM E119 or UL 263 shall not apply to the flame barriers or vertical separation unless otherwise required by the provisions of this code.
Exceptions:
  1. This section shall not apply to buildings that are three stories or less above grade plane.
  2. This section shall not apply to buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  3. Open parking garages.

diagrams.title: Vertical Separation of Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
If openings in adjacent stories are within 5 horizontal feet of one another, and the opening in the lower story has a fire protection rating of less than 3/4 hour, the openings must be separated vertically by at least 3 feet by spandrel girders, exterior walls or other similar assemblies that have a minimum fire-resistance rating of 1 hour. The spandrel area needs to be rated for exposure to fire from both the interior and exterior. Another acceptable opening separation is a flame barrier. The barrier must project a minimum or 30" and be of 1 hr minimum fire-resistance rating.

Exceptions:
  1. This section does not apply to buildings that are three stories or less above grade plane.
  2. This section does not apply to buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  3. This section does not apply to open parking garages.

children.body:
For buildings on the same lot, opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour shall be provided in every opening that is less than 15 feet (4572 mm) vertically above the roof of an adjacent building or structure based on assuming an imaginary line between them. The opening protectives are required where the fire separation distance between the imaginary line and the adjacent building or structure is less than 15 feet (4572 mm).
Exceptions:
  1. Opening protectives are not required where the roof assembly of the adjacent building or structure has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour for a minimum distance of 10 feet (3048 mm) from the exterior wall facing the imaginary line and the entire length and span of the supporting elements for the fire-resistance-rated roof assembly has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour.
  2. Buildings on the same lot and considered as portions of one building in accordance with Section 705.3 are not required to comply with Section 705.8.6.

diagrams.title: Buildings on Same Lot: Vertical Exposure
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Buildings on the same lot but that are of different heights may require protection of the upper windows against fire that could be coming from a fire at the adjacent lower building. This code section does not address a requirement for the wall itself to be fire rated, but the opening to have protection. Table 602 would govern the required fire rating based on the fire-separation distance. However, if the wall between the buildings is a fire wall, then 706.6.1 would apply, which requires a fire rating of the 15 feet that extend beyond the lower building.

children.body:
Notwithstanding Table 705.8, exterior walls of buildings with a fire separation distance of 15 feet (4572 mm) or less shall be permitted to have openings if the building (i) contains occupancies other than Group H, and (ii) is equipped throughout with sprinklers in accordance with Section 903, subject to the restrictions of Sections 705.8.7.1 through 705.8.7.8.
Exceptions:
  1. Nothing in this code shall be construed to allow mechanical or plumbing openings in exterior walls that would not otherwise be allowed by this code or by the Mechanical Code or Plumbing Code.
  2. Openings allowed pursuant to this section shall not be counted towards requirements of the Construction Codes for emergency egress, natural light, natural ventilation, or smoke control.
  3. Buildings on the same lot and considered as portions of one building in accordance with Section 705.3 are not required to comply with Sections 705.8.7.1 through 705.8.7.6.
children.displayTitle: 705.8.7 At-Risk Openings Allowed Fifteen (15) Feet or Less From Adjacent Structures or Premises
children.titleText: At-Risk Openings Allowed Fifteen (15) Feet or Less From Adjacent Structures or Premises

children.body: A limited number of door openings between two abutting buildings, protected in accordance with Section 705.8.7.5, shall be permitted when: (a) the openings are approved by the code official as not posing an undue hazard to life safety; (b) the owners of both buildings provide written authorization for the openings; and (c) both buildings are subject to the covenant required by Section 705.8.7.8.

Those stories that directly face other buildings or structures located either on the same lot or on an adjacent lot, having a distance between buildings of 15 feet (4572 mm) or less, shall comply with Sections 705.8.7.2.1 through 705.8.7.2.3.

Those portions of the exterior walls of a story that directly face another structure and have a distance to the adjacent structure of less than 3 feet (914 mm) shall have no openings, unless permitted by Table 705.8.
children.displayTitle: 705.8.7.2.1 Exposure by Adjacent Structure Less Than Three Feet Away
children.titleText: Exposure by Adjacent Structure Less Than Three Feet Away

children.body: Those portions of the exterior walls of a story that directly face another structure and have a distance to the adjacent structure of 3 feet (914 mm) to less than 10 feet (3046 mm) shall have no more than 45 percent openings.
children.displayTitle: 705.8.7.2.2 Exposure by Adjacent Structure Between Three and Ten Feet Away
children.titleText: Exposure by Adjacent Structure Between Three and Ten Feet Away

children.body: Those portions of the exterior walls of a story that directly face another structure and have a distance to the adjacent structure of 10 feet (3046 mm) to less than 15 feet (4572 mm) shall comply with Section 705.8.7.2.2 or with Table 705.8.
children.displayTitle: 705.8.7.2.3 Exposure by Adjacent Structure Between Ten and Fifteen Feet
children.titleText: Exposure by Adjacent Structure Between Ten and Fifteen Feet

children.body: Those stories that extend higher than the adjacent building or premises, but do not project over the adjacent building or premises, shall comply with Sections 705.8.7.3.1 and 705.8.7.3.2.

No openings are allowed in those portions of the exterior walls of a story that meet both of the following conditions: (a) the vertical projection of the exterior wall is less than 3 feet (914 mm) horizontally from the vertical projection of the nearest edge of the adjacent or adjoining structure or premises; and (b) the portions of the exterior walls of the story are less than 12 feet (3658 mm) above the level of the roof of the adjacent or adjoining structure or the grade of the adjacent or adjoining premises.
Exceptions:
  1. When a registered architect or engineer has certified that the adjacent roof assembly and the entire length and span of its supporting elements have a fire resistance rating of not less than one hour, openings shall be allowed in the portions of those exterior walls that are more than 3 feet (914 mm) above the level of the roof. The maximum area of openings allowed under this exception shall be 45 percent of the area of such portions of the exterior wall.
    1. Where there are skylights or other unprotected openings in the roof of the adjacent exposing building that are less than 10 feet (3048 mm) from the vertical projection of the exterior wall of the opposing exposed building, the percentage of openings allowed under Section 705.8.7.2.2, Exception 1, shall be reduced to the following percentages of the exterior wall of the exposed building:
      1. 0 feet up to 3 feet (0 mm up to 914 mm) from roof opening to wall: 0 percent.
      2. 3 feet up to 5 feet (914 mm up to 1524 mm) from roof opening to wall: 15 percent.
      3. 5 feet up to 10 feet (1524 mm up to 3048 mm) from roof opening to wall: 25 percent.
  2. When a registered professional engineer has submitted a written report of inspection certifying that the adjacent building is protected throughout with an automatic fire sprinkler system conforming to Section 903.3, openings shall be allowed in the portions of the exterior walls that are more than 3 feet (914 mm) above the level of the roof. The maximum area of openings allowed under this exception shall be 45 percent of the area of such portions of the exterior wall.

In those portions of the exterior walls of a story that are 3 feet (914 mm) or greater horizontally from the vertical projection of the nearest edge of the adjacent structure or premises, and less than 15 feet (4572 mm) above the level of the roof of the adjacent structure or above the grade of the adjacent premises, a maximum area of openings of 45 percent of such portions of the exterior wall, calculated story by story and for each wall face, shall be allowed, where any one of the following conditions occur:
  1. The openings are protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour; or
  2. The roof assembly of the adjacent exposing building or structure, and the entire length and span of its supporting elements, have a fire-resistance rating of not less than one hour for a minimum distance of 10 feet (3048 mm) from the vertical projection of the exposed exterior wall.
    Exception: Where there are skylights or other unprotected openings in the roof of the adjacent exposing building that are less than 10 feet (3048 mm) from the vertical projection of the exterior wall of the exposed building, the percentage of openings allowed under condition (b) of this Section 705.8.7.3.2 shall be reduced to the following percentages:
    1. 0 feet up to 3 feet (0 mm up to 914 mm) from roof opening to wall: 0 percent.
    2. 3 feet up to 5 feet (914 mm up to 1524 mm) from roof opening to wall: 15 percent.
    3. 5 feet up to 10 feet (1524 mm up to 3048 mm) from roof opening to wall: 25 percent.
children.displayTitle: 705.8.7.3.2 Greater Than or Equal to Three Feet Horizontally
children.titleText: Greater Than or Equal to Three Feet Horizontally

children.body: In portions of the exterior walls of any story, other than those specified in Sections 705.8.7.1 through 705.8.7.3, openings up to the maximum of 45 percent of those portions of the exterior wall, calculated story by story and for each wall face, shall be authorized. Openings in compliance with Table 705.8 shall also be authorized.

Where openings are authorized by Sections 705.8.7.1 through 705.8.7.4, such openings shall be protected as required by Sections 705.8.7.1 through 705.8.7.4, and window openings shall be protected by tempered, wired, or laminated glass, installed in compliance with Section 716.6. Mechanical and door openings shall be protected in compliance with Sections 716.5 or 717.5.6.

The owner of the building where openings are authorized pursuant to Sections 705.8.7.1 through 705.8.7.5. is responsible for making any modifications in the openings, the exterior wall, or appurtenant protective systems necessary to maintain the building's compliance with this code, whenever changes occur in the exterior envelope of any building or premises within a distance of 15 feet (4572 mm) or less of that exterior wall that render the openings no longer compliant with this code. The owner of the building with the resulting non-compliant openings shall complete all actions required to make the openings compliant with this code, as determined by the code official, including but not limited to: closing of openings; upgrading of opening protectives; and removal or extension of parts of the required sprinkler system protecting the openings.

If the owner of a building or structure where any openings in exterior walls were allowed pursuant to Sections 705.8.7.1 through 705.8.7.6 fails to maintain in working order the protective systems required, or fails to proceed to make any changes required by the code official under Section 705.8.7.5, the code official is authorized to cause the necessary work to be done, in the interest of the safety and welfare of the public, in accordance with D.C. Official Code §§ 6-801 et seq. (2018 Repl.) and any other applicable laws and regulations. The cost of work shall become a lien against the property of the offending owner, to be recovered by the District of Columbia through appropriate action.

Prior to issuance of a building permit authorizing work that includes openings authorized under Sections 705.8.7.1 through 705.8.7.7, the applicant shall execute and record a covenant in accordance with the requirements of Section 106.2.19 and Section 120 as applicable to ensure that compliance with the minimum requirements of Sections 705.8.7.1 through 705.8.7.7 will be maintained for as long as the openings shall exist, and that the responsibility to maintain this compliance will be conveyed to any future owner of the building or holder of an interest therein.

Joints made in or between exterior walls required by this section to have a fire-resistance rating shall comply with Section 715.
Exception: Joints in exterior walls that are permitted to have unprotected openings.
The void created at the intersection of a floor/ceiling assembly and an exterior curtain wall assembly shall be protected in accordance with Section 715.4.

diagrams.title: Voids at Curtain Wall Intersections
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To prevent the interior spread of fire the code requires that the void between a fire-resistance-rated floor or floor/ceiling assemblies and an exterior curtain wall needs to be filled with an approved perimeter fire containment system. The perimeter fire containment system is required to have an F rating for a time period not less than the fire-resistance rating of the floor or floor/ceiling assembly.

children.body:
Penetrations by air ducts and air transfer openings in fire-resistance-rated exterior walls required to have protected openings shall comply with Section 717.
Exception: Foundation vents installed in accordance with this code are permitted.

diagrams.title: Vent Termination Locations at Ext. Walls (IMC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Mechanical vent terminations are required to maintain minimum distances from openings so as not to contaminate fresh air intake into the building. Also verify requirements with the manufacturer's specifications.

children.body:
Parapets shall be provided on exterior walls of buildings.
Exceptions: A parapet need not be provided on an exterior wall where any of the following conditions exist:
  1. The wall is not required to be fire-resistance rated in accordance with Table 602 because of fire separation distance.
  2. The building has an area of not more than 1,000 square feet (93 m2) on any floor.
  3. Walls that terminate at roofs of not less than 2-hour fire-resistance-rated construction or where the roof, including the deck or slab and supporting construction, is constructed entirely of noncombustible materials.
  4. One-hour fire-resistance-rated exterior walls that terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing, deck or slab, provided:
    1. Where the roof/ceiling framing elements are parallel to the walls, such framing and elements supporting such framing shall not be of less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction for a width of 4 feet (1220 mm) for Groups R and U and 10 feet (3048 mm) for other occupancies, measured from the interior side of the wall.
    2. Where roof/ceiling framing elements are not parallel to the wall, the entire span of such framing and elements supporting such framing shall not be of less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction.
    3. Openings in the roof shall not be located within 5 feet (1524 mm) of the 1-hour fire-resistance-rated exterior wall for Groups R and U and 10 feet (3048 mm) for other occupancies, measured from the interior side of the wall.
    4. The entire building shall be provided with not less than a Class B roof covering.
  5. In Groups R-2 and R-3 where the entire building is provided with a Class C roof covering, the exterior wall shall be permitted to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck in Type III, IV and V construction, provided one or both of the following criteria is met:
    1. The roof sheathing or deck is constructed of approved noncombustible materials or of fire-retardant-treated wood for a distance of 4 feet (1220 mm).
    2. The roof is protected with 0.625-inch (16 mm) Type X gypsum board directly beneath the underside of the roof sheathing or deck, supported by not less than nominal 2-inch (51 mm) ledgers attached to the sides of the roof framing members for a minimum distance of 4 feet (1220 mm).
  6. Where the wall is permitted to have not less than 25 percent of the exterior wall areas containing unprotected openings based on fire separation distance as determined in accordance with Section 705.8.

diagrams.title: Example: Conc. Parapet Wall
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This example shows a concrete parapet wall that backs up the brick facade, and is secured to a concrete/metal deck.

children.body: Parapets shall have the same fire-resistance rating as that required for the supporting wall, and on any side adjacent to a roof surface, shall have noncombustible faces for the uppermost 18 inches (457 mm), including counterflashing and coping materials. The height of the parapet shall be not less than 30 inches (762 mm) above the point where the roof surface and the wall intersect. Where the roof slopes toward a parapet at a slope greater than two units vertical in 12 units horizontal (16.7-percent slope), the parapet shall extend to the same height as any portion of the roof within a fire separation distance where protection of wall openings is required, but in no case shall the height be less than 30 inches (762 mm).

diagrams.title: Parapet Const.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.11.1 defines the required fire protection and height of parapet walls. The fire resistance rating of the parapet wall is required to be same as the wall below that is supporting the parapet. The wall below may have different ratings required for the interior and exterior sides depending on the construction type and fire separation distance.

Additional wall top protection of the parapet is required as follows:First, the top of the parapet needs to be protected by noncombustible coping. Second, on faces of the parapet adjacent to a roof the top 18" must be protected by a noncombustible facing. This requirement also applies to any counterflashing that may occur in the same region of the parapet wall face.

The minimum required parapet wall height is 30" above where the roof surface and wall intersect. The parapet height may need to be increased if the roof slopes towards the parapet at greater than 2:12 slope, or if the height of the roof at the fire separation distance that defines the limit of where protection of wall openings is greater than 30" above where the roof meets the parapet wall. In this case, the minimum parapet height is required to be the height of the roof at which the fire separation distance requires protection of wall openings.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. When roofs on either side of the firewall slope towards the fire-wall with a slope exceeding 2 in 12 the fire wall height needs to be at least 30" above the roof deck within 4' of the firewall.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. If the provisions of NFPA 221 are used, only allows this condition for Type I and II construction, whereas the building code does not explicitly say the entire building must be of Type I or II construction. It only addresses the roof construction.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions
Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Horiz. Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Fire walls have special requirements for horizontal continuity at or beyond the exterior face of the building. If the wall is not extended 18" beyond the face of the exterior wall, then special attention must be given to the interface and construction of the fire wall to extend into the construction of the exterior wall to the backside of the exterior sheathing or finishes. In addition the types of exterior sheathing or finishes determines the requirements for opening protection within four feet each side of the wall. If the angle of the intersecting walls are more than 180 degrees, it becomes more difficult for a fire to "end run" around the end of the fire wall, and requirements on these intersecting walls becomes less.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls Supporting Combustible Framing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combustible members embedded in concrete or masonry walls are required to maintain a minimum of solid or fireblocked material between ends of adjacent wood members. This prevents a condition where the combustible material burns out and creates an opening through which smoke, heat and fire can pass.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Structural Req. and Duct Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Note that while non-hazardous ducts may be allowed through fire walls in certain conditions by the building code, exhaust ducts may not be allowed to penetrate a fire wall in any circumstance. Verify requirements with the adopted mechanical code.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections (Excpt. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

T
he code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections (Excpt. 2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 6
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. When roofs on either side of the firewall slope towards the fire-wall with a slope exceeding 2 in 12 the fire wall height needs to be at least 30" above the roof deck within 4' of the firewall.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 5
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation required for podium buildings by Section 510.2, the fire wall may start at the top of the rated podium assembly.

diagrams.title: Single Bldgs. Divided by Fire Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In new construction, for the purposes of determining area limitations, height limitations and type of construction, each portion of a building separated by one or more fire walls complying with Section 706 shall be considered to be a separate building.

Where adopted, the Existing Building Code (IEBC) allows under very certain conditions the use of a fire barrier in lieu of a fire wall when there is a change of occupancy for lower hazard uses. Frequently, it would be very difficult to provide a fully code compliant fire wall in many of these situations.

diagrams.title: Marking of Fire Rated Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In older buildings, fire-rated walls are harder to spot for an electrician installing boxes or running cables and conduits. Only someone familiar with wall construction and occupancy types will know which walls of an older building are required to be fire-resistance rated. The required markings let those installing future work know that fire-rated penetrations and openings require special consideration so that an unsafe condition is not created by not providing proper fire-rated construction for openings and penetrations.

Verify the exact wording required for your jurisdiction. Note that wording required by the Life Safety Code, if adopted, requires that the type of fire-resistive assembly be identified, whereas the Building Code provides suggested wording. Older versions of the Life Safety Code, such as that required by CMS doesn't appear to have the same requirement.

diagrams.title: Duct Coverings: Penetration of Assemblies Prohibited
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a wall or floor with a required fire-resistance rating is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor. Where a wall or floor that is required to be fireblocked is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor.

diagrams.title: Anchor Buildings and Mall Fire Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Mall anchor buildings are to be separated from a mall building by fire walls in compliance with section 706. Where the anchor building is 3 or less stories above grade plane and the same occupancy as the mall tenant spaces a 2 hour rated fire barrier may be used in place of the fire walls. Where an anchor building is separated from an open mall building with an open mall the exterior walls of the anchor building need to comply with the requirements of table 705.5.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke Damper Locations - Fire Wall & Fire Barriers
Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Base Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected. Other exceptions also apply.

children.body: Each portion of a building separated by one or more fire walls that comply with the provisions of this section shall be considered a separate building. The extent and location of such fire walls shall provide a complete separation. Where a fire wall also separates occupancies that are required to be separated by a fire barrier wall, the most restrictive requirements of each separation shall apply.

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours. Per 704.1 any structure supporting the first floor assembly would likewise also need to have the same 1-1/2 hour fire protection rating.

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours.

children.body:
Any wall that straddles, or is in close proximity to, a lot line, which is used for structural support by two or more adjoining buildings or structures shall be constructed as a fire wall in accordance with Section 706. Such walls shall be constructed without openings and shall create separate buildings.
Exceptions:
  1. Openings allowed pursuant to Section 705.8.7, provided that the owners of the adjacent buildings shall provide written authorization for such openings to each other and both buildings are subject to the covenant required by Section 705.8.7.8.
  2. Openings in a party wall separating an anchor building and a covered or open mall building shall be in accordance with Section 402.4.2.2.

diagrams.title: Single Bldgs. Divided by Fire Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In new construction, for the purposes of determining area limitations, height limitations and type of construction, each portion of a building separated by one or more fire walls complying with Section 706 shall be considered to be a separate building.

Where adopted, the Existing Building Code (IEBC) allows under very certain conditions the use of a fire barrier in lieu of a fire wall when there is a change of occupancy for lower hazard uses. Frequently, it would be very difficult to provide a fully code compliant fire wall in many of these situations.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

children.body: Fire walls shall be designed and constructed to allow collapse of the structure on either side without collapse of the wall under fire conditions. Fire walls designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA 221 shall be deemed to comply with this section.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls Supporting Combustible Framing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combustible members embedded in concrete or masonry walls are required to maintain a minimum of solid or fireblocked material between ends of adjacent wood members. This prevents a condition where the combustible material burns out and creates an opening through which smoke, heat and fire can pass.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Structural Req. and Duct Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Note that while non-hazardous ducts may be allowed through fire walls in certain conditions by the building code, exhaust ducts may not be allowed to penetrate a fire wall in any circumstance. Verify requirements with the adopted mechanical code.

children.body:
Fire walls shall be of any approved noncombustible materials.
Exception: Buildings of Type V construction.

Fire walls shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than that required by Table 706.4.

TABLE 706.4
FIRE WALL FIRE-RESISTANCE RATINGS
GROUP FIRE-RESISTANCE RATING (hours)
A, B, E, H-4, I, R-1, R-2, U 3a
F-1, H-3b, H-5, M, S-1 3
H-1, H-2 4b
F-2, S-2, R-3, R-4 2

  1. In Type II or V construction, walls shall be permitted to have a 2-hour fire-resistance rating.
  2. For Group H-1, H-2 or H-3 buildings, also see Sections 415.7 and 415.8.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly.

children.body:
Fire walls shall be continuous from exterior wall to exterior wall and shall extend not less than 18 inches (457 mm) beyond the exterior surface of exterior walls.
Exceptions:
  1. Fire walls shall be permitted to terminate at the interior surface of combustible exterior sheathing or siding provided the exterior wall has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour for a horizontal distance of not less than 4 feet (1220 mm) on both sides of the fire wall. Openings within such exterior walls shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour.
  2. Fire walls shall be permitted to terminate at the interior surface of noncombustible exterior sheathing, exterior siding or other noncombustible exterior finishes provided the sheathing, siding or other exterior noncombustible finish extends a horizontal distance of not less than 4 feet (1220 mm) on both sides of the fire wall.
  3. Fire walls shall be permitted to terminate at the interior surface of noncombustible exterior sheathing where the building on each side of the fire wall is protected by an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Horiz. Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Fire walls have special requirements for horizontal continuity at or beyond the exterior face of the building. If the wall is not extended 18" beyond the face of the exterior wall, then special attention must be given to the interface and construction of the fire wall to extend into the construction of the exterior wall to the backside of the exterior sheathing or finishes. In addition the types of exterior sheathing or finishes determines the requirements for opening protection within four feet each side of the wall. If the angle of the intersecting walls are more than 180 degrees, it becomes more difficult for a fire to "end run" around the end of the fire wall, and requirements on these intersecting walls becomes less.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections (Excpt. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

T
he code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections (Excpt. 2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

children.body:
Where the fire wall intersects exterior walls, the fire-resistance rating and opening protection of the exterior walls shall comply with one of the following:
  1. The exterior walls on both sides of the fire wall shall have a 1-hour fire-resistance rating with 3/4-hour protection where opening protection is required by Section 705.8. The fire-resistance rating of the exterior wall shall extend not less than 4 feet (1220 mm) on each side of the intersection of the fire wall to exterior wall. Exterior wall intersections at fire walls that form an angle equal to or greater than 180 degrees (3.14 rad) do not need exterior wall protection.
  2. Buildings or spaces on both sides of the intersecting fire wall shall assume to have an imaginary lot line at the fire wall and extending beyond the exterior of the fire wall. The location of the assumed line in relation to the exterior walls and the fire wall shall be such that the exterior wall and opening protection meet the requirements set forth in Sections 705.5 and 705.8. Such protection is not required for exterior walls terminating at fire walls that form an angle equal to or greater than 180 degrees (3.14 rad).

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

children.body:
Fire walls shall extend to the outer edge of horizontal projecting elements such as balconies, roof overhangs, canopies, marquees and similar projections that are within 4 feet (1220 mm) of the fire wall.
Exceptions:
  1. Horizontal projecting elements without concealed spaces, provided the exterior wall behind and below the projecting element has not less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction for a distance not less than the depth of the projecting element on both sides of the fire wall. Openings within such exterior walls shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour.
  2. Noncombustible horizontal projecting elements with concealed spaces, provided a minimum 1-hour fire-resistance-rated wall extends through the concealed space. The projecting element shall be separated from the building by not less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction for a distance on each side of the fire wall equal to the depth of the projecting element. The wall is not required to extend under the projecting element where the building exterior wall is not less than 1-hour fire-resistance rated for a distance on each side of the fire wall equal to the depth of the projecting element. Openings within such exterior walls shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour.
  3. For combustible horizontal projecting elements with concealed spaces, the fire wall need only extend through the concealed space to the outer edges of the projecting elements. The exterior wall behind and below the projecting element shall be of not less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction for a distance not less than the depth of the projecting elements on both sides of the fire wall. Openings within such exterior walls shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire-protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. T

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.
