children.body:
Fire walls shall extend from the foundation to a termination point not less than 30 inches (762 mm) above both adjacent roofs.
Exceptions:
  1. Stepped buildings in accordance with Section 706.6.1.
  2. Two-hour fire-resistance-rated walls shall be permitted to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing, deck or slab, provided:
    1. The lower roof assembly within 4 feet (1220 mm) of the wall has not less than a 1-hour fire-resistance rating and the entire length and span of supporting elements for the rated roof assembly has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour.
    2. Openings in the roof shall not be located within 4 feet (1220 mm) of the fire wall.
    3. Each building shall be provided with not less than a Class B roof covering.
  3. Walls shall be permitted to terminate at the underside of noncombustible roof sheathing, deck or slabs where both buildings are provided with not less than a Class B roof covering. Openings in the roof shall not be located within 4 feet (1220 mm) of the fire wall.
  4. In buildings of Type III, IV and V construction, walls shall be permitted to terminate at the underside of combustible roof sheathing or decks, provided:
    1. There are no openings in the roof within 4 feet (1220 mm) of the fire wall,
    2. The roof is covered with a minimum Class B roof covering, and
    3. The roof sheathing or deck is constructed of fire-retardant-treated wood for a distance of 4 feet (1220 mm) on both sides of the wall or the roof is protected with 5/8-inch (15.9 mm) Type X gypsum board directly beneath the underside of the roof sheathing or deck, supported by not less than 2-inch (51 mm) nominal ledgers attached to the sides of the roof framing members for a distance of not less than 4 feet (1220 mm) on both sides of the fire wall.
  5. In buildings designed in accordance with Section 510.2, fire walls located above the 3-hour horizontal assembly required by Section 510.2, Item 1 shall be permitted to extend from the top of this horizontal assembly.
  6. Buildings with sloped roofs in accordance with Section 706.6.2.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. When roofs on either side of the firewall slope towards the fire-wall with a slope exceeding 2 in 12 the fire wall height needs to be at least 30" above the roof deck within 4' of the firewall.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. If the provisions of NFPA 221 are used, only allows this condition for Type I and II construction, whereas the building code does not explicitly say the entire building must be of Type I or II construction. It only addresses the roof construction.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 6
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. When roofs on either side of the firewall slope towards the fire-wall with a slope exceeding 2 in 12 the fire wall height needs to be at least 30" above the roof deck within 4' of the firewall.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 5
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation required for podium buildings by Section 510.2, the fire wall may start at the top of the rated podium assembly.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Type IIIA Height Increases
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 510.5 is a variation on the idea of a horizontal separation to allow for increased building height for a specific building type. For Type III-A, R-1/R-2 buildings that provide compartmentalization by means of fire walls, increased height is permitted. Fire walls should extend all the way to the basement. The horizontal separation is for a specific use and is not used to create two separate buildings, as Section 510.2 does.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Base Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected. Other exceptions also apply.

children.body:
Where a fire wall serves as an exterior wall for a building and separates buildings having different roof levels, such wall shall terminate at a point not less than 30 inches (762 mm) above the lower roof level, provided the exterior wall for a height of 15 feet (4572 mm) above the lower roof is not less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction from both sides with openings protected by fire assemblies having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour.
Exception: Where the fire wall terminates at the underside of the roof sheathing, deck or slab of the lower roof, provided:
  1. The lower roof assembly within 10 feet (3048 mm) of the wall has not less than a 1-hour fire-resistance rating and the entire length and span of supporting elements for the rated roof assembly has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour.
  2. Openings in the lower roof shall not be located within 10 feet (3048 mm) of the fire wall.

Where a fire wall serves as an interior wall for a building, and the roof on one side or both sides of the fire wall slopes toward the fire wall at a slope greater than two units vertical in 12 units horizontal (2:12), the fire wall shall extend to a height equal to the height of the roof located 4 feet (1219 mm) from the fire wall plus 30 inches (762 mm). In no case shall the extension of the fire wall be less than 30 inches (762 mm).

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 6
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. When roofs on either side of the firewall slope towards the fire-wall with a slope exceeding 2 in 12 the fire wall height needs to be at least 30" above the roof deck within 4' of the firewall.

children.body: Adjacent combustible members entering into a concrete or masonry fire wall from opposite sides shall not have less than a 4-inch (102 mm) distance between embedded ends. Where combustible members frame into hollow walls or walls of hollow units, hollow spaces shall be solidly filled for the full thickness of the wall and for a distance not less than 4 inches (102 mm) above, below and between the structural members, with noncombustible materials approved for fireblocking.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls Supporting Combustible Framing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combustible members embedded in concrete or masonry walls are required to maintain a minimum of solid or fireblocked material between ends of adjacent wood members. This prevents a condition where the combustible material burns out and creates an opening through which smoke, heat and fire can pass.

children.body:
Each opening through a fire wall shall be protected in accordance with Section 716.5 and shall not exceed 156 square feet (15 m2) in total area. The aggregate width of openings at any floor level shall not exceed 25 percent of the length of the wall.
Exceptions:
  1. Openings are not permitted in party walls constructed in accordance with Section 706.1.1, unless authorized by and subject to the limitations of Section 705.8.7.
  2. Openings are allowed pursuant to Section 705.8.7 where a fire wall can be replaced by two exterior walls.
  3. Openings shall not be limited to 156 square feet (15 m2) where both buildings are equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.

diagrams.title: Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
Buildings on the Same Lot - Excpt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 addresses the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already has a building on it. One has to have an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines to apply the section correctly. To comply with the base condition the designer needs to establish a fire separation line on the site that is in compliance with the existing buildings exterior wall and opening protectives. Once that line is located the new building may be designed as if the newly established line is a property line. Exception 1 allows for the new building and existing buildings to be considered one structure and eliminates the fire separation protectives required by the imaginary fire separation line of the base condition.

Exception 1 applies limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type on the site.

Exception 2 only applies when an S-2 parking garage of type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. Zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage is required for the exception. 1-1/2 hr fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts with the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with 706.8 which limits single opening size and aggregate width of openings relative the wall length.

diagrams.title: Fire Protective vs. Fire Resistive Glazing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Diagram adapted from SaftiFirst product literature.

children.body: Penetrations of fire walls shall comply with Section 714.
Joints made in or between fire walls shall comply with Section 715.

Ducts and air transfer openings shall not penetrate fire walls.
Exception: Penetrations by ducts and air transfer openings of fire walls that are not on a lot line shall be allowed provided the penetrations comply with Section 717. The size and aggregate width of all openings shall not exceed the limitations of Section 706.8.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Structural Req. and Duct Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Note that while non-hazardous ducts may be allowed through fire walls in certain conditions by the building code, exhaust ducts may not be allowed to penetrate a fire wall in any circumstance. Verify requirements with the adopted mechanical code.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions
Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Two Story Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In other than Groups I-2 and I-3, a vertical opening that is not used as one of the applications listed in Building Code Section 712.1, such as an atrium or escalator opening, is allowed. If an opening connecting stories is used for listed purposes, other requirements apply. If a two-story opening is used per 712.1.9, the opening must comply with all of the following items:
  1. Does not connect more than two stories.
  2. Does not penetrate a horizontal assembly that separates fire areas or smoke barriers that separate smoke compartments.
  3. Is not concealed within the construction of a wall or a floor/ceiling assembly.
  4. Is not open to a corridor in Group I and R occupancies.
  5. Is not open to a corridor on nonsprinklered floors.
  6. Is separated from floor openings and air transfer openings serving other floors by construction conforming to required shaft enclosures.

According to Section 713, shaft enclosures shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707.

diagrams.title: Fire-Resistance Ratings of Control Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Control areas are required to be separated from one another by either fire barriers or horizontal assemblies. The fire barrier fire-resistance rating is determined in Table 414.2.2 and depends on the percentage of the maximum allowable quantity that will be stored within the control area and the story the control area is located on. Horizontal assemblies and their associated supporting structure are required to have a 2 hour fire-resistance rating except in buildings of type IIA, IIIA, IV or VA construction that are 3 stories or less and have a sprinkler system install throughout.

diagrams.title: Shafts and Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shaft enclosures and shaft bottoms are required to provide separation between the building and those shafts which communicate between floors. If for functionality a shaft is to open to the space below, like a laundry chute, then the rating requirement is broaded to include the room in which it opens to.

diagrams.title: Supporting Construction for Fire Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Structural members and assemblies that support a fire barrier are required to have the same or higher fire-resistance rating as the barrier being supported. Hollow vertical spaces within the barrier need to be fireblocked at every floor level as per Section 718.2. There is an exception for assemblies supporting fire barriers for tank storage where a maximum fire-resistance rating of 2 hours, or the minimum specified by Table 601 for the building type is required. There is an exception for construction supporting 1-hour fire barriers in buildings of Types IIB, IIIB, and VB unless mandated by other code sections.

diagrams.title: Fire Barrier Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In this example, a 1-hour fire barrier interesects a 2-hour horizontal floor assembly. The fire barrier must extend up through any concealed spaces in the floor ceiling assembly. Certain exceptions exist for shaft, stairway and exit-passageway enclosures.

diagrams.title: Marking of Fire Rated Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In older buildings, fire-rated walls are harder to spot for an electrician installing boxes or running cables and conduits. Only someone familiar with wall construction and occupancy types will know which walls of an older building are required to be fire-resistance rated. The required markings let those installing future work know that fire-rated penetrations and openings require special consideration so that an unsafe condition is not created by not providing proper fire-rated construction for openings and penetrations.

Verify the exact wording required for your jurisdiction. Note that wording required by the Life Safety Code, if adopted, requires that the type of fire-resistive assembly be identified, whereas the Building Code provides suggested wording. Older versions of the Life Safety Code, such as that required by CMS doesn't appear to have the same requirement.

diagrams.title: Duct Coverings: Penetration of Assemblies Prohibited
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a wall or floor with a required fire-resistance rating is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor. Where a wall or floor that is required to be fireblocked is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Separated Occupancy Requirements
Fire & Smoke Damper Locations - Fire Wall & Fire Barriers
Voids at Intersections of Fire Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a fire barrier comes up to meet a nonfire-rated roof and voids are created between the wall and roof, the voids must be filled with an approved fire safing material. All of the voids for the entire length of the intersection are required to be filled. The fill must be install in the void or on the intersection such that it will not dislodge or loosen due to expected building movement. The fill must be installed such that it will retard the passage of fire and hot gasses from one side of the wall to the other.

children.body: Fire barriers installed as required elsewhere in this code or the International Fire Code shall comply with this section.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated wall assemblies are of three varieties: fire walls, fire barriers and fire partitions. Fire barriers can be used as shaft enclosures, occupancy separations and others. Fire partitions are often used as demising walls and corridor separations, among other uses.

diagrams.title: Fire Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: FIRE BARRIER. A fire-resistance-rated wall assembly of materials designed to restrict the spread of fire in which continuity is maintained.

children.body: Fire barriers shall be of materials permitted by the building type of construction.
The fire-resistance rating of fire barriers shall comply with this section.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Supporting Construction for Fire Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Structural members and assemblies that support a fire barrier are required to have the same or higher fire-resistance rating as the barrier being supported. Hollow vertical spaces within the barrier need to be fireblocked at every floor level as per Section 718.2. There is an exception for assemblies supporting fire barriers for tank storage where a maximum fire-resistance rating of 2 hours, or the minimum specified by Table 601 for the building type is required. There is an exception for construction supporting 1-hour fire barriers in buildings of Types IIB, IIIB, and VB unless mandated by other code sections.

children.body: The fire-resistance rating of the fire barrier separating building areas from a shaft shall comply with Section 713.4.

diagrams.title: Shafts and Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shaft enclosures and shaft bottoms are required to provide separation between the building and those shafts which communicate between floors. If for functionality a shaft is to open to the space below, like a laundry chute, then the rating requirement is broaded to include the room in which it opens to.

diagrams.title: Vertical Duct Shaft Bottom
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This is one example of the detailing of a shaft bottom with concrete and steel deck floor construction. The horizontal assembly requires an extra layer of gypsum board due to the fact that the heat from a fire would (initially) be more intense at the underside directly above a fire, than at the vertical face of the shaft. Source: oshpd.ca.gov. OPD No. FR4.02

diagrams.title: Example: Shaft Wall Termination - Precast Panel
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This is one example of a joint at the intersection of a precast panel (likely an exterior curtain wall) and a fire barrier acting as a shaft wall. Source: oshpd.ca.gov. OPD No. FR1.40

children.body: The fire-resistance rating of the fire barrier separating building areas from an interior exit stairway or ramp shall comply with Section 1023.1.

diagrams.title: Interior Stair & Ramp Exterior Wall Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The exterior walls of interior exit stairway enclosures only need to meet the typical exterior wall requirements for the building based on its fire separation distance as defined in section 705. Where the exit stairway exterior wall is non-rated or has unprotected openings and the angle between the adjacent wall and the exterior wall of the exit stairway is less than 180 degrees, the first 10' of the immediately adjacent wall is required to have a fire-resistance rating of 1 hour or more and 3/4 hour opening protection. The fire-rated wall and opening protection needs to be provided vertically from the ground up to 10' above the top floor landing or the roof line, whichever is lower. If the exterior wall of the exit stairway is rated and its openings are protected the wall immediately adjacent to the exit stairway may be constructed based on the fire separation distance per section 705.

diagrams.title: Ext. Walls of Int. Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior walls of interior exit stairs and ramps aren't always required to meet a fire resistance rating. Section 1023.7 requires protection against fire exposure to non-rated walls of interior exit stair/ramp enclosures. Protection must be provided for building walls exposing the stair/ramp wall within 180 degrees. A minimum 1-hour fire rating is required within 10 feet of the exit wall. The designer has the option of meeting the fire rating either at the stair/ramp wall, or the building wall causing the exposure. Openings in the required protection distance of 10 feet shall be minimum 3/4 hour rated.

children.displayTitle: 707.3.2 Interior Exit Stairway and Ramp Construction
children.titleText: Interior Exit Stairway and Ramp Construction

children.body: The fire-resistance rating of the fire barrier separating building areas from an exit access stairway or ramp shall comply with Section 713.4.
The fire-resistance rating of the fire barrier separating building areas from an exit passageway shall comply with Section 1024.3.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Exterior Walls (IBC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At a minimum, the exterior wall of an exit passageway must comply with section 705, which defines how exterior walls may be constructed in relation to the design fire separation distance. When the exterior wall of an exit passageway is fire rated and openings within the wall are protected no additional measures are required on the exterior walls within 10' of the passageway beyond what section 705 calls for. When the exterior wall of an exit passageway is nonrated and openings within the wall are unprotected no additional measures are required on the exterior of the building provided the exit passageway exterior wall aligns with or is proud of (in front of) all adjacent exterior walls within 10' horizontally of the exit passageway exterior wall. When the exterior wall of an exit passageway is nonrated or has unprotected opening and an adjacent exterior wall meets the passageway wall at an angle of less than 180 degrees, such that the adjacent wall within 10' of the passageway wall is proud of the passageway wall, the adjacent wall shall be 1 hour fire-resistance rated within 10' of the passageway and openings within the same 10' of the adjacent wall shall have a 3/4 hour fire-protection rating. The fire-resistant construction and opening protections where required within 10' of the passageway must extend from the ground to 10' above the passageway floor or the roof line, whichever is lower.

children.body: The fire-resistance rating of the separation between building areas connected by a horizontal exit shall comply with Section 1026.1.

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A horizontal exit compartmentalizes a building allowing occupants to exit the area containing the origin of a fire into another portion of the building that is protected by fire-resistance-rated assemblies (doors, walls, ceilings, and floors). A horizontal exit separates a space into two exit access areas. Code requirements for horizontal exits address fire-rated separation, opening protectives, capacity, and other features.

children.body: The fire-resistance rating of the fire barrier separating atriums shall comply with Section 404.6.
The fire barrier separating incidental uses from other spaces in the building shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than that indicated in Table 509.
Fire barriers separating control areas shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than that required in Section 414.2.4.

diagrams.title: Hazmat Control Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
HazMat MAQ (Section 304.4 → 414.2 → 307.1) - To determine fire protection, construction, and other requirements where hazardous materials are used or stored, the maximum allowable quantity (MAQ) must be determined. To do this the material type, class, state, and use must be known. The quantity will then determine what class of Group H the facility will be considered as. For Group M or Group S occupancies the MAQ differs. Once the MAQ and occupancy group has been determined the construction requirements of WBC 414.2 and the fire protection requirements of WFC Chapter 9 and the specific chapter based on the material, can be established.

When we put these steps together, here is how the process should work:
  1. As the owner of "Widget Business Solutions", I find that there is a need for organic peroxides on site. I start by going to the table in Table 307.1(1) of the building code. This table outlines the MAQ per control area.
  2. In the "Material" column I find 'organic peroxides'. I see that there are different allowances based on class. Further, research into my product reveals that this is a Class III organic peroxide (these burn rapidly and present a moderate reactivity hazard).
  3. Next I need to determine in what state the material will be in. Per the table, the only options available are Solid or Liquid. The material will be utilized in its solid form. It will only be stored, not used (in a closed or open system). Under the column labeled "Storage" and "solid pounds" I see that I can house 125 cubic feet of Class III organic peroxides per single control area. This would classify the occupancy as a Group H-2. If the storage amount was to exceed 125 cubic feet (where permitted), then the occupancy would change to Group H-3.

children.body: Where the provisions of Section 508.4 are applicable, the fire barrier separating mixed occupancies shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than that indicated in Table 508.4 based on the occupancies being separated.

diagrams.title: Non Separated vs. Separated Occ.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The use of separated and non-separated occupancies is two of the three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

Non-separated occupancies offer more open planning options and reduced wall construction, but come at the cost of treating the entire building (or portion thereof) as the most restrictive occupancy group. This affects not only allowable area and height, but also fire protection features—especially under Chapter 9, where sprinkler requirements, fire alarms, and smoke control systems must meet the higher standard across the board. From an implementation standpoint, non-separated occupancies are simpler to document but more limiting for maximizing usable area, particularly when integrating high-intensity uses like Assembly (Group A-3) with lower-risk uses like Business (Group B).

Separated occupancies require rated fire barriers and/or rated horizontal assemblies between different occupancy groups per Section 508.4. In addition the structural systems supporting these barriers must also themselves be rated. This introduces complexity in detailing, cost, and coordination across MEP penetrations and egress paths. However, this separation allows each occupancy to retain its own allowable area, height, and fire protection approach, often resulting in better yield for multi-use buildings.

Non-separation of occupancy groups does not eliminate the need for fire ratings related to specific features, such as corridors, control areas, shafts, an atrium, two-story openings, etc. In these situations, the specific code requirements for separations must be used even if the overall building is considered non-separated, as the separation is a condition of the specific feature, such as an atrium or opening between levels (See Section 712.1.9).

Similarly, "separation" is only recognized where a rated assembly is continuous and properly detailed—meaning partial separations, stub walls, or incomplete barriers do not count toward code compliance. Architects must engage early with code consultants and AHJs to align expectations, especially when pursuing performance-based design or leveraging exceptions (e.g., Section 510 for podium construction or control areas for hazardous materials) that can further complicate occupancy separations.

children.body:
The fire barriers or horizontal assemblies, or both, separating a single occupancy into different fire areas shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than that indicated in Table 707.3.10. The fire barriers or horizontal assemblies, or both, separating fire areas of mixed occupancies shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than the highest value indicated in Table 707.3.10 for the occupancies under consideration.
TABLE 707.3.10
FIRE-RESISTANCE RATING REQUIREMENTS FOR FIRE BARRIER ASSEMBLIES OR HORIZONTAL ASSEMBLIES BETWEEN FIRE AREAS
OCCUPANCY GROUP FIRE-RESISTANCE RATING (hours)
H-1, H-2 4
F-1, H-3, S-1 3
A, B, E, F-2, H-4, H-5,
I, M, R, S-2		 2
U 1

diagrams.title: Example: Fire Areas (Group M)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Area: The aggregate floor area enclosed and bounded by fire walls, fire barriers, exterior walls or horizontal assemblies of a building. Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included in the fire area if such areas are included within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor next above.

When sprinklers are required for a fire area, it does not necessarily make it a "sprinklered building" for use in Chapter 5, unless it is "Sprinklered Throughout" in accordance with NFPA 13, 13R or 13D, as applicable. In addition, the separations are also not necessarily the same concept as separated occupancies found in Section 508. However fire barriers used for fire area separation may also be used as occupancy separations found in Section 508 if the most stringent of each fire rating requirements are met.

diagrams.title: Fire Areas: Multi. Occ., Non-Rated vs. Rated Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
For non-separated occupancies, Section 508.3.1 states the most restrictive provision of Chapter 9 shall apply to the entire area. Therefore, even though there are no limits to B Occupancy fire areas, when combined with an F-1 Occupancy, for example, the 12,000 sq. ft. limit would apply to the total area of F-1 and B.

UpCodes Note: This is a separate concept from separated occupancies found in Section 508. However fire barriers used for fire area separation may also be used as occupancy separations found in Section 508 if both fire rating requirements are met.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Fire Areas: Additions to Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When an existing building's size is increased, it must comply with the fire protection requirements of chapter 9 of the building code. An addition is defined as, "An extension or increase in floor area, number of stories, or height of a building or structure." For building additions, the existing building code must be consulted. Additions are specifically addressed in Ch. 11. The user note at the beginning of this chapter states that,"...contains the minimum requirements for an addition that is not separated from the existing building by a fire wall…"

In our example we have a Group A-2 occupancy that is currently 3,000 sq. ft., as is no fire sprinkler protection is required. An addition to the building will increase the total area to 6,000 sq. ft. Based on the fire protection requirements for a Group A-2 in the building code section 903.2.1.2, an A-2 that exceeds 5,000 sq.ft. is required to be equipped throughout with an automatic fire sprinkler system.

Alternatively, if a fire sprinkler was not to be installed, the new addition could be separated from the existing by a fire-rated wall. As long as each fire area remains below the requirements for sprinklering, none would be required.

children.body:
Where exterior walls serve as a part of a required fire-resistance-rated shaft or stairway or ramp enclosure, or separation, such walls shall comply with the requirements of Section 705 for exterior walls and the fire-resistance-rated enclosure or separation requirements shall not apply.
Exception: Exterior walls required to be fire-resistance rated in accordance with Section 1021 for exterior egress balconies, Section 1023.7 for interior exit stairways and ramps and Section 1027.6 for exterior exit stairways and ramp.

diagrams.title: Stair Enclosures at Exterior Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairway enclousure walls are intended to provide a specific hourly fire resistance from a fire occurring within the same building. Therefore they are required for adjoining interior walls, but not necessarily exterior walls. However, if the walls are near to a property line fire-separation distance datum line, then the building itself, which includes the stairway, must still be protected from outside hazards as an exterior wall of a building would. Keep in mind that stairways also have an occupancy group, and that occupancy group is required to determine the required exterior wall fire rating.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection - Exception 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection - Exception 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection - Exception 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

children.body:
Fire barriers shall extend from the top of the foundation or floor/ceiling assembly below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, slab or deck above and shall be securely attached thereto. Such fire barriers shall be continuous through concealed space, such as the space above a suspended ceiling. Joints and voids at intersections shall comply with Sections 707.8 and 707.9
Exceptions:
  1. Shaft enclosures shall be permitted to terminate at a top enclosure complying with Section 713.12.
  2. Interior exit stairway and ramp enclosures required by Section 1023 and exit access stairway and ramp enclosures required by Section 1019 shall be permitted to terminate at a top enclosure complying with Section 713.12.

diagrams.title: Cricket (Unrated) at Prop. Line
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Crickets at property lines may be able to be unrated if less than 30" max. height and the roof sheathing for a 4 foot distance on each side is fire-retardant treated. Check with local jurisdictions for suitability and applicability.

Source: 2019 Oregon Residential Specialty Code Section R302.2.6.3 - "Unrated cricket less than or equal to 30 inches."

diagrams.title: Cricket (Rated) at Prop. Line
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
This is but one way to provide a continuous fire rated assembly at a large wood framed cricket when required.

Source: Oregon Residential Specialty Code Section R302.2.3.1 - "Wood Cricket Greater Than 30" in Height"

diagrams.title: Example: Suspended Ceiling Slip Joint Plan: Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Suspended ceilings should be braced against lateral movement and against vertical movement due to seismic forces to prevent falling and/or buckling. Such a failure not only endangers the occupants from the supported fixtures, but a failed suspended ceiling can also block egress doors. Free joints allow for the movement of ceilings and walls in a way that does not contribute to compression induced buckling of suspended ceiling members.

source: oshpd.ca.gov OPD CL2.30

diagrams.title: Example: Suspended Ceiling Bracing
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Suspended ceilings should be braced against lateral movement and against vertical movement due to seismic forces to prevent falling and/or buckling. Such a failure not only endangers the occupants from the supported fixtures, but a failed suspended ceiling can also block egress doors.

source: hcai.ca.gov OPD CL2.10

diagrams.title: Fire Assembly Continuity: Framed Roof
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
This is but one way to provide a continuous fire rated assembly at a wood framed roof attic enclosure.

Source: Oregon Residential Specialty Code Section R302.2.3.1 - "Fire-resistance-rated Roof/Ceiling Construction - "Mushroom" Attic Enclosure Framing Parallel to Common Property Line"

diagrams.title: Example: Interior Metal Stud Partition / Concrete Slab Firestopping
Fire Barrier Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In this example, a 1-hour fire barrier interesects a 2-hour horizontal floor assembly. The fire barrier must extend up through any concealed spaces in the floor ceiling assembly. Certain exceptions exist for shaft, stairway and exit-passageway enclosures.

children.body:
The supporting construction for a fire barrier shall be protected to afford the required fire-resistance rating of the fire barrier supported. Hollow vertical spaces within a fire barrier shall be fireblocked in accordance with Section 718.2 at every floor level.
Exceptions:
  1. The maximum required fire-resistance rating for assemblies supporting fire barriers separating tank storage as provided for in Section 415.9.1.2 shall be 2 hours, but not less than required by Table 601 for the building construction type.
  2. Supporting construction for 1-hour fire barriers required by Table 509 in buildings of Type IIB, IIIB and VB construction is not required to be fire-resistance rated unless required by other sections of this code.

diagrams.title: Supporting Construction for Fire Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Structural members and assemblies that support a fire barrier are required to have the same or higher fire-resistance rating as the barrier being supported. Hollow vertical spaces within the barrier need to be fireblocked at every floor level as per Section 718.2. There is an exception for assemblies supporting fire barriers for tank storage where a maximum fire-resistance rating of 2 hours, or the minimum specified by Table 601 for the building type is required. There is an exception for construction supporting 1-hour fire barriers in buildings of Types IIB, IIIB, and VB unless mandated by other code sections.

children.body:
Openings in a fire barrier shall be protected in accordance with Section 716. Openings shall be limited to a maximum aggregate width of 25 percent of the length of the wall, and the maximum area of any single opening shall not exceed 156 square feet (15 m2). Openings in enclosures for exit access stairways and ramps, interior exit stairways and ramps and exit passageways shall also comply with Sections 1019, 1023.4 and 1024.5, respectively.
Exceptions:
  1. Openings shall not be limited to 156 square feet (15 m2 ) where adjoining floor areas are equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903. 3.1.1.
  2. Openings shall not be limited to 156 square feet (15 m2 ) or an aggregate width of 25 percent of the length of the wall where the opening protective is a fire door serving enclosures for exit access stairways and ramps, and interior exit stairways and ramps.
  3. Openings shall not be limited to 156 square feet (15 m2 ) or an aggregate width of 25 percent of the length of the wall where the opening protective has been tested in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263 and has a minimum fire-resistance rating not less than the fire-resistance rating of the wall.
  4. Fire window assemblies permitted in atrium separation walls shall not be limited to a maximum aggregate width of 25 percent of the length of the wall.
  5. Openings shall not be limited to 156 square feet (15 m2) or an aggregate width of 25 percent of the length of the wall where the opening protective is a fire door assembly in a fire barrier separating an enclosure for exit access stairways and ramps, and interior exit stairways and ramps from an exit passageway in accordance with Section 1023.3.1.

diagrams.title: Fire Protective vs. Fire Resistive Glazing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Diagram adapted from SaftiFirst product literature.

children.body: Penetrations of fire barriers shall comply with Section 714.

Penetrations into enclosures for exit access stairways and ramps, interior exit stairways and ramps, and exit passageways shall be allowed only where permitted by Sections 1019, 1023.5 and 1024.6, respectively.

Joints made in or between fire barriers, and joints made at the intersection of fire barriers with underside of a fire-resistance-rated floor or roof sheathing, slab or deck above, and the exterior vertical wall intersection shall comply with Section 715.

diagrams.title: Example: Control Joint - Rated Partition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Control joints in gypsum board fire-rated assemblies are required to be designed to prevent the passage of fire. The example shown is but one option for providing this using gypsum board as the joint protection. source: oshpd.ca.gov. OPD No. FR3.05

diagrams.title: Example: Control Joint - Gyp. Board Partitions with Mineral Wool
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Control joints in gypsum board fire-rated assemblies are required to be designed to prevent the passage of fire. The example shown is but one option for providing this. Verify the applicable UL listing with the products used to ensure proper specification and installation. Source: Source: oshpd.ca.gov. OPD No. FR3.04

diagrams.title: Example: Interior Metal Stud Partition / Concrete Slab Firestopping

children.body: The voids created at the intersection of a fire barrier and a nonfire-resistance-rated roof assembly or a nonfire-resistance-rated exterior wall assembly shall be filled. An approved material or system shall be used to fill the void, and shall be securely installed in or on the intersection for its entire length so as not to dislodge, loosen or otherwise impair its ability to accommodate expected building movements and to retard the passage of fire and hot gases.

diagrams.title: Voids at Intersections of Fire Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a fire barrier comes up to meet a nonfire-rated roof and voids are created between the wall and roof, the voids must be filled with an approved fire safing material. All of the voids for the entire length of the intersection are required to be filled. The fill must be install in the void or on the intersection such that it will not dislodge or loosen due to expected building movement. The fill must be installed such that it will retard the passage of fire and hot gasses from one side of the wall to the other.

children.body: Penetrations in a fire barrier by ducts and air transfer openings shall comply with Section 717.

diagrams.title: Exit Discharge: Exception 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When more than one interior egress stair is required, egress from some of the interior exit stairways up to 50% of the required egress stairways capacity may be through a vestibule. The code only allows egress through a vestibule under certain conditions which must all be met. If there is space below the vestibule the floor must be constructed to the same fire-resistance rating as the interior exit stairway enclosure. The size of the vestibule is limited to 10 deep from the exterior face by 30' in length. The vestibule walls must separate the vestibule from the remaining level of exit discharge with fire partitions in accordance with section 708. The vestibule space may only be used as a means of egress and exit directly to the outside.

diagrams.title: Fire Partitions: Dwelling and Sleeping Units
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire partitions are generally required in the following locations:
  1. Walls separating sleeping and/or dwelling units In I-1 and Group R occupancies
  2. Walls separating tenants in open or covered mall buildings
  3. Corridor walls where required by section 1020.0
  4. Walls enclosing elevator lobbies that provide hoistway opening protection
  5. Walls separating egress balconies where required by section 1021.2

diagrams.title: Exit Discharge: Exception 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When an interior exit stairway discharges into and exits through another space all of the following conditions need to be met. Not more than 50% of the required capacity or minimum required width of the interior egress stairs may exit through the area. Upon entering the area from the interior exit stairway an exterior exit needs to be readily visible and identifiable along with a free and unobstructed path of travel to the exterior exit. The area being exited through must be separated from areas below by an assembly conforming to the same fire-resistance requirements as the interior exit stairway enclosure. The through exit area must be protected throughout by an approved sprinkler system. Other areas at the level of exit discharge need to be either separated from the through exit area with assemblies conforming to the same fire-resistance requirements as the interior exit stairway enclosure or protected throughout by an approved sprinkler system. When an exit access stair and a required interior exit stairway that serve the same floor both exit through the same exit space the interior exit stairway exit door and the exit access stairway need a minimum separation distance of 30' or not less than one-fourth the length of the maximum overall diagonal dimension of the building, whichever is less.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions
Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Marking of Fire Rated Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In older buildings, fire-rated walls are harder to spot for an electrician installing boxes or running cables and conduits. Only someone familiar with wall construction and occupancy types will know which walls of an older building are required to be fire-resistance rated. The required markings let those installing future work know that fire-rated penetrations and openings require special consideration so that an unsafe condition is not created by not providing proper fire-rated construction for openings and penetrations.

Verify the exact wording required for your jurisdiction. Note that wording required by the Life Safety Code, if adopted, requires that the type of fire-resistive assembly be identified, whereas the Building Code provides suggested wording. Older versions of the Life Safety Code, such as that required by CMS doesn't appear to have the same requirement.

diagrams.title: Duct Coverings: Penetration of Assemblies Prohibited
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a wall or floor with a required fire-resistance rating is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor. Where a wall or floor that is required to be fireblocked is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor.

children.body:
The following wall assemblies shall comply with this section.
  1. Separation walls as required by Section 420.2 for Groups I-1, R-1, R-2 and R-3.
  2. Walls separating tenant spaces in covered and open mall buildings as required by Section 402.4.2.1.
  3. Corridor walls as required by Section 1020.1.
  4. Elevator lobby separation as required by Section 3006.2.
  5. Egress balconies as required by Section 1021.2.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated wall assemblies are of three varieties: fire walls, fire barriers and fire partitions. Fire barriers can be used as shaft enclosures, occupancy separations and others. Fire partitions are often used as demising walls and corridor separations, among other uses.

diagrams.title: Fire Partitions: Egress Balcony Wall Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire partitions are generally required in the following locations:
  1. Walls separating sleeping and/or dwelling units
  2. Walls separating tenants in open or covered mall buildings
  3. Corridor walls where required by section 1020.1
  4. Walls enclosing elevator lobbies that provide hoistway opening protection
  5. Walls separating egress balconies where required by section 1021.2

diagrams.title: Exit Separation Distance with Rated Corridors - Excpt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: If exit stair enclosures are connected with a one-hour rated corridor, the required exit separation distance can be measured along the shortest direct line of travel within the corridor instead of the standard one-half of the diagonal of the area served (Building Code, Reference: 1007.1.1, Exception 1). The corridor must conform to the requirements of Sections 1020 and 708.

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Wall Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1021.2 establishes requirements for the separation between an exterior egress balcony and the interior of the building. In most cases, the wall between interior rooms and the exterior egress balcony needs to meet corridor separation standards, using fire partitions and protected openings. The diagram's left-hand example illustrates this standard situation for a single stairway configuration—architects should design with an assumption that any window or door along the egress balcony must have proper rated protection, as would any opening facing into a corridor.
Single Stairways and Opening Protection
The use of a single stairway is a crucial factor: when only one exit stairway is provided, you do not benefit from the separation exception. This means all doors and windows along the egress balcony must be protected as required for corridors. This is intended to ensure a safe, protected evacuation path in projects where there is no alternate escape route. If openings are left unprotected, it can create a hazardous condition—potential fire and smoke spread from adjacent units or rooms directly to the egress route.

Possible exceptions and edge cases
A common point of confusion arises with occupancy-specific exceptions found in different code sections. While some occupancies may not require corridor protection at certain openings (as listed in Table 1020.2 or elsewhere in the code), this does not generally apply to egress balconies with only one stairway—unless those same occupancies are exempted from corridor separation, the wall and opening protection requirements still apply. For projects utilizing two or more stairways, as depicted in the right-hand diagram, and for layout configurations that avoid dead-end travel past unprotected openings, you can eliminate these wall and protective opening requirements. The key is verifying both multiple egress paths and the absence of dead-end travel conditions for your specific occupancy and balcony arrangement.

diagrams.title: Fire Partitions: Dwelling and Sleeping Units
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire partitions are generally required in the following locations:
  1. Walls separating sleeping and/or dwelling units In I-1 and Group R occupancies
  2. Walls separating tenants in open or covered mall buildings
  3. Corridor walls where required by section 1020.0
  4. Walls enclosing elevator lobbies that provide hoistway opening protection
  5. Walls separating egress balconies where required by section 1021.2

children.body: The walls shall be of materials permitted by the building type of construction.

Fire partitions shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour.
Exceptions:
  1. Corridor walls permitted to have a 1/2-hour fire-resistance rating by Table 1020.1.
  2. Dwelling unit and sleeping unit separations in buildings of Type IIB, IIIB and VB construction shall have fire-resistance ratings of not less than 1/2 hour in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.

children.body:
Fire partitions shall extend from the top of the foundation or floor/ceiling assembly below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, slab or deck above or to the fire-resistance-rated floor/ceiling or roof/ceiling assembly above, and shall be securely attached thereto. In combustible construction where the fire partitions are not required to be continuous to the sheathing, deck or slab, the space between the ceiling and the sheathing, deck or slab above shall be fireblocked or draftstopped in accordance with Sections 718.2 and 718.3 at the partition line. The supporting construction shall be protected to afford the required fire-resistance rating of the wall supported, except for walls separating tenant spaces in covered and open mall buildings, walls separating dwelling units, walls separating sleeping units and corridor walls, in buildings of Type IIB, IIIB and VB construction.
Exceptions:
  1. The wall need not be extended into the crawl space below where the floor above the crawl space has a minimum 1-hour fire-resistance rating.
  2. Where the room-side fire-resistance-rated membrane of the corridor is carried through to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck or slab of a fire-resistance-rated floor or roof above, the ceiling of the corridor shall be permitted to be protected by the use of ceiling materials as required for a 1-hour fire-resistance-rated floor or roof system.
  3. Where the corridor ceiling is constructed as required for the corridor walls, the walls shall be permitted to terminate at the upper membrane of such ceiling assembly.
  4. The fire partitions separating tenant spaces in a covered or open mall building, complying with Section 402.4.2.1, are not required to extend beyond the underside of a ceiling that is not part of a fire-resistance-rated assembly. A wall is not required in attic or ceiling spaces above tenant separation walls.
  5. Attic fireblocking or draftstopping is not required at the partition line in Group R-2 buildings that do not exceed four stories above grade plane, provided the attic space is subdivided by draftstopping into areas not exceeding 3,000 square feet (279 m2) or above every two dwelling units, whichever is smaller.
  6. Fireblocking or draftstopping is not required at the partition line in buildings equipped with an automatic sprinkler system installed throughout in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2, provided that automatic sprinklers are installed in combustible floor/ceiling and roof/ceiling spaces.

diagrams.title: Fire Partition Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Construction requirements for fire partitions include continuity to floors above or below and foundations to preclude the passage of fire and smoke from one area to another, to prevent an "end-run" effect that would compromise the protection provided.

diagrams.title: Cricket (Unrated) at Prop. Line
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Crickets at property lines may be able to be unrated if less than 30" max. height and the roof sheathing for a 4 foot distance on each side is fire-retardant treated. Check with local jurisdictions for suitability and applicability.

Source: 2019 Oregon Residential Specialty Code Section R302.2.6.3 - "Unrated cricket less than or equal to 30 inches."

diagrams.title: Cricket (Rated) at Prop. Line
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
This is but one way to provide a continuous fire rated assembly at a large wood framed cricket when required.

Source: Oregon Residential Specialty Code Section R302.2.3.1 - "Wood Cricket Greater Than 30" in Height"

diagrams.title: Fire Assembly Continuity: Framed Roof
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
This is but one way to provide a continuous fire rated assembly at a wood framed roof attic enclosure.

Source: Oregon Residential Specialty Code Section R302.2.3.1 - "Fire-resistance-rated Roof/Ceiling Construction - "Mushroom" Attic Enclosure Framing Parallel to Common Property Line"

children.body:
Where exterior walls serve as a part of a required fire-resistance-rated separation, such walls shall comply with the requirements of Section 705 for exterior walls, and the fire-resistance-rated separation requirements shall not apply.
Exception: Exterior walls required to be fire-resistance rated in accordance with Section 1021.2 for exterior egress balconies, Section 1023.7 for interior exit stairways and ramps and Section 1027.6 for exterior exit stairways and ramps.

diagrams.title: Area of Refuge Access to Stairway or Elevator
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Areas of refuge are fire-resistance rated and smoke protected areas where those unable to use stairs can register a call for evacuation assistance and await instructions or assistance. They must provide direct access to an exit stairway (or to an elevator equipped with standby power). Horizontal exits can substitute for areas of refuge.

When areas of refuge are not designed to be directly in the stairway enclosure, the area of refuge must generally be directly adjacent to the stairway, accessible means-of-egress elevator. An exception exists for an interior area of refuge at the level of exit discharge that provides direct access to an exterior exit door. These are not required to be located adjacent to a stair or accessible means of egress elevator.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions
Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies

children.body: Vertical and horizontal smoke barriers shall comply with this section.
Smoke barriers shall be of materials permitted by the building type of construction.

A 1-hour fire-resistance rating is required for smoke barriers.
Exception: Smoke barriers constructed of minimum 0.10-inch-thick (2.5 mm) steel in Group I-3 buildings.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. children.body:
Smoke barriers shall form an effective membrane continuous from the top of the foundation or floor/ ceiling assembly below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck or slab above, including continuity through concealed spaces, such as those found above suspended ceilings, and interstitial structural and mechanical spaces. The supporting construction shall be protected to afford the required fire-resistance rating of the wall or floor supported in buildings of other than Type IIB, IIIB or VB construction. Smoke barrier walls used to separate smoke compartments shall comply with Section 709.4.1. Smoke-barrier walls used to enclose areas of refuge in accordance with Section 1009.6.4 or to enclose elevator lobbies in accordance with Section 405.4.3, 3007.6.2, or 3008.6.2 shall comply with Section 709.4.2.
Exception: Smoke-barrier walls are not required in interstitial spaces where such spaces are designed and constructed with ceilings or exterior walls that provide resistance to the passage of fire and smoke equivalent to that provided by the smoke-barrier walls.

diagrams.title: Example: Suspended Ceiling Slip Joint Plan: Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Suspended ceilings should be braced against lateral movement and against vertical movement due to seismic forces to prevent falling and/or buckling. Such a failure not only endangers the occupants from the supported fixtures, but a failed suspended ceiling can also block egress doors. Free joints allow for the movement of ceilings and walls in a way that does not contribute to compression induced buckling of suspended ceiling members.

source: oshpd.ca.gov OPD CL2.30

diagrams.title: Example: Suspended Ceiling Bracing
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Suspended ceilings should be braced against lateral movement and against vertical movement due to seismic forces to prevent falling and/or buckling. Such a failure not only endangers the occupants from the supported fixtures, but a failed suspended ceiling can also block egress doors.

source: hcai.ca.gov OPD CL2.10

children.body: Smoke-barrier walls used to separate smoke compartments shall form an effective membrane continuous from outside wall to outside wall.

Smoke-barrier walls used to enclose areas of refuge in accordance with Section 1009.6.4, or to enclose elevator lobbies in accordance with Section 405.4.3, 3007.6.2, or 3008.6.2, shall form an effective membrane enclosure that terminates at a fire barrier wall having a level of fire protection rating not less than 1 hour, another smoke barrier wall or an outside wall. A smoke and draft control door assembly as specified in Section 716.5.3.1 shall not be required at each elevator hoistway door opening or at each exit doorway between an area of refuge and the exit enclosure.
children.displayTitle: 709.4.2 Smoke-Barrier Walls Enclosing Areas of Refuge or Elevator Lobbies
children.titleText: Smoke-Barrier Walls Enclosing Areas of Refuge or Elevator Lobbies

children.body:
Openings in a smoke barrier shall be protected in accordance with Section 716.
Exceptions:
  1. In Group I-1 Condition 2, Group I-2 and ambulatory care facilities, where a pair of opposite-swinging doors are installed across a corridor in accordance with Section 709.5.1, the doors shall not be required to be protected in accordance with Section 716. The doors shall be close fitting within operational tolerances, and shall not have a center mullion or undercuts in excess of 3/4 inch (19.1 mm), louvers or grilles. The doors shall have head and jamb stops, and astragals or rabbets at meeting edges. Where permitted by the door manufacturer's listing, positive-latching devices are not required.
  2. In Group I-1 Condition 2, Group I-2 and ambulatory care facilities, horizontal sliding doors installed in accordance with Section 1010.1.4.3 and protected in accordance with Section 716.

diagrams.title: Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies

children.body: In Group I-2 and ambulatory care facilities, where doors are installed across a corridor, the doors shall be automatic-closing by smoke detection in accordance with Section 716.5.9.3 and shall have a vision panel with fire-protection-rated glazing materials in fire-protection-rated frames, the area of which shall not exceed that tested.
children.displayTitle: 709.5.1 Group I-2 and Ambulatory Care Facilities
children.titleText: Group I-2 and Ambulatory Care Facilities

children.body: Penetrations of smoke barriers shall comply with Section 714.
Joints made in or between smoke barriers shall comply with Section 715.
Penetrations in a smoke barrier by ducts and air transfer openings shall comply with Section 717.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions
Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Smoke Partition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The purpose of smoke partitions is to restrict the movement of smoke within a building by forming a continuous membrane extending from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck, or slab above or the underside of the ceiling above (Section 710.4). They are designed to limit the free passage of smoke and are required to have specific materials, openings, and penetrations that meet established standards in order to prevent smoke from spreading throughout the building (710.2, 710.5, 710.6). Smoke partitions are not required to have a fire-resistance rating unless required elsewhere in the code (710.3).

diagrams.title: Marking of Fire Rated Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In older buildings, fire-rated walls are harder to spot for an electrician installing boxes or running cables and conduits. Only someone familiar with wall construction and occupancy types will know which walls of an older building are required to be fire-resistance rated. The required markings let those installing future work know that fire-rated penetrations and openings require special consideration so that an unsafe condition is not created by not providing proper fire-rated construction for openings and penetrations.

Verify the exact wording required for your jurisdiction. Note that wording required by the Life Safety Code, if adopted, requires that the type of fire-resistive assembly be identified, whereas the Building Code provides suggested wording. Older versions of the Life Safety Code, such as that required by CMS doesn't appear to have the same requirement.

children.body: Smoke partitions installed as required elsewhere in the code shall comply with this section.
The walls shall be of materials permitted by the building type of construction.

diagrams.title: Smoke Partition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The purpose of smoke partitions is to restrict the movement of smoke within a building by forming a continuous membrane extending from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck, or slab above or the underside of the ceiling above (Section 710.4). They are designed to limit the free passage of smoke and are required to have specific materials, openings, and penetrations that meet established standards in order to prevent smoke from spreading throughout the building (710.2, 710.5, 710.6). Smoke partitions are not required to have a fire-resistance rating unless required elsewhere in the code (710.3).

children.body: Unless required elsewhere in the code, smoke partitions are not required to have a fire-resistance rating.

children.body: Smoke partitions shall extend from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck or slab above or to the underside of the ceiling above where the ceiling membrane is constructed to limit the transfer of smoke.

diagrams.title: Smoke Partition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The purpose of smoke partitions is to restrict the movement of smoke within a building by forming a continuous membrane extending from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck, or slab above or the underside of the ceiling above (Section 710.4). They are designed to limit the free passage of smoke and are required to have specific materials, openings, and penetrations that meet established standards in order to prevent smoke from spreading throughout the building (710.2, 710.5, 710.6). Smoke partitions are not required to have a fire-resistance rating unless required elsewhere in the code (710.3).

children.body: Openings in smoke partitions shall comply with Sections 710.5.1 and 710.5.2.

diagrams.title: Smoke Partition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The purpose of smoke partitions is to restrict the movement of smoke within a building by forming a continuous membrane extending from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck, or slab above or the underside of the ceiling above (Section 710.4). They are designed to limit the free passage of smoke and are required to have specific materials, openings, and penetrations that meet established standards in order to prevent smoke from spreading throughout the building (710.2, 710.5, 710.6). Smoke partitions are not required to have a fire-resistance rating unless required elsewhere in the code (710.3).

children.body: Windows in smoke partitions shall be sealed to resist the free passage of smoke or be automatic-closing upon detection of smoke.
Doors in smoke partitions shall comply with Sections 710.5.2.1 through 710.5.2.3.

diagrams.title: Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
